—On the point of order, Madam President, it seems to be rather a spurious point of order to take to say that the minister cannot be expected to provide information to the Senate because he is ignorant. Normally in that circumstance a minister would take a question on notice. As we saw earlier in question time today you have allowed questions under those circumstances where matters have been taken on notice. It has been a long-standing procedure for supplementary questions to be asked. If the minister does not know he ought to take it on notice and provide those answers.

—Madam President, on the point of order, there is no obligation on any minister to take a question on notice when it is made blindingly apparent that the minister has no knowledge of the question. How can any supplementary take the matter any further? By definition there is nothing more that the supplementary could seek to elicit other than to put some more grubby sleaze on the public record. That is the real purpose of that supplementary question. Senator Cook knows he cannot expect an answer in view of the first answer he got. He is simply using this vehicle to retail the sort of stuff he would never be prepared to say outside the chamber. That is the place it ought to be dealt with, not in question time.

—On the point of order, Madam President, what we have here today is a question being asked of a minister representing the minister responsible for corporate affairs. The opposition are entitled to ask questions and we are entitled to expect an answer. We have for many years had a situation where ministers unable to answer questions have taken matters on notice and further information has been sought in a supplementary. I suggest to you, Madam President, that this question and supplementary are entirely within order.

—The senator is entitled to ask his supplementary question. He may get the same answer he got the first time. There may be something more that he concludes with that the minister would want to respond to. I will listen to the rest of the question.

—Thank you, Madam President. Doesn't this mean that if there are 10 individual beneficiaries between the three family trusts then Senator Heffernan can distribute $54,000 tax free whereas an Australian worker would pay $15,984 in tax on that same amount? Minister, if this is not tax avoidance, what is?

—Order! We are in question time. Senator Cook has asked a supplementary question and I wish to call the minister in response. Senators will cease shrieking at each other across the chamber and carrying on in breach of the standing orders.

—In the old days, when Senator Ray had some principles, one of his principles was `10 yards to courage'—if you want to attack somebody, you walk out of this chamber and you attack that person. Senator Cook, my answer to your question and your attack on my colleague is `10 yards to courage.'

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Will the minister advise the Senate of the Howard government's record of strong financial management? Will he also advise the Senate of our commitment to repaying debt and improving the economy for all Australians?
—I think the person who represents the Minister for Finance in this chamber actually is my colleague, Senator Ellison. I will leave it to Senator Ellison to answer.
—Did he bugger up a dorothy dixer?
—The mistake may have been mine in terms of what I thought Senator Chapman had said. There was so much noise in the chamber it is surprising anybody knows what is going on.

—Order! The behaviour in the chamber is absolutely outrageous and unacceptable and in breach of the standing orders. I remind senators that behaving in a way that is persistently and wilfully in breach of the standing orders may be reported to the Senate.
—Talking across the chamber when I am speaking is also disorderly.

—Thank you, Madam President, and can I say what a good question this is. Senator Chapman has had a longstanding interest in matters financial and of course heads up the corporations and securities committee, and has contributed greatly to this subject over the years in the Senate. The running of the nation's finances is the responsibility of the federal government and taxpayers expect their federal government to apply their taxes wisely and for the benefit of all Australians. It is therefore fitting that this government do that and also plan for the future and take advantage of the good economic climate that we are experiencing at the moment. This is what we are doing, in stark contrast to Labor at the beginning of this decade when it ran up debt, ran up a deficit and incurred heavy borrowings. At the end of this decade Australians are enjoying prosperity and optimism which has not been seen in a generation. In fact, the Prime Minister has said that now is the time to take the opportunities which are being offered to us by the next millennium and use them.
—You tell the press gallery!

—We have cause for optimism, and there are a number of reasons, I might say to Senator Murphy: the growth rate of over four per cent a year, six consecutive quarters of over one per cent in growth—a historical record in this nation's history.
—Don't look up there. They're leaving; they're on their bike.
—They're clearing the room.
—Order! An intelligent interjection that relates to the topic can be tolerated; the sort of sledging that has been going on today is absolutely intolerable.
—What the opposition does not want to hear is what Westpac is saying about the growth rate of this country. It says:

answer.para: Overall, the Leading Index for Australia continues to signal that Australia's growth will be maintained at a very healthy pace, certainly much faster than predicted by both the government in their recent Budget papers, and the Reserve Bank.

That is a great commendation of the government's economic policy, but there is more. Prices: inflation exceptionally low, as recognised by the Reserve Bank. Wages: real wages have been rising, primarily due to rising productivity. Now the opposition does not want to hear this because it is embarrassing, because of their record earlier on in this decade when they mismanaged this country's finances. Interest rates: six times since July 1996 we have seen interest rates cut. Credit rating: we have now had a credit rating of AA-plus restored; it is an international recognition of this country's economy policy and the right decisions that this government is making on the financial scene.

But what about employment? Unemployment is a continual problem and we are committed to fighting it. We are committed to lowering the unemployment rate—7.5 per cent seasonally adjusted, the lowest rate we have had in years. Again, that is further cause for optimism and Australians are beginning to realise that this country is at the dawn of a new era, a great era of economic prosperity and opportunity. Now is the time that we should be paying off our debts, and it stands to reason: when you run your own finances and you are enjoying an income, you put something away for a rainy day. You pay off your debts and you save money, and that is what we should be doing as a government for future generations of Australians. But of course the opposition do not want to listen to this because what they did at the beginning of this decade was run up a huge debt; they had $96 billion worth of debt. In fact, in the four or five years prior to them losing government, they ran up in excess of $58 billion of debt. You would not run your household finances that way at all and the Australian people recognised this in October last year when they rejected their economic policies. Why doesn't the opposition join us—get on that bandwagon of tax reform, turning around the economy and taking up those opportunities for all Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister please give further advice to the Senate on the very great importance that this government places on repaying debt and the benefit that the Australian economy will derive from that.

—The paying off of debt is a crucial part of this question, and it was Senator Peter Walsh, as he then was in 1985—a member of the Labor government then—who said that `paying interest on public debt obviously gives governments a good deal less flexibility than they would have otherwise in making their expenditure decision.' It was recognised by members of the opposition that paying off debt was very important. We recognise this in the way that we are looking at handling the proceeds of the sale of Telstra part 2. What we are going to do is apply that to paying off debt, so that we will not have to pay $8 billion a year interest on debt. That money, if we had no debt, could go to providing more services to Australians—and that is good management.

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that Senator Heffernan, the Parliamentary Secretary to Cabinet, has stated that the use of trusts by farmers to reduce tax is `essential to keep family farms operating and enable farmers to pass their properties on to their children'? That is from the Herald and Weekly Times of 11 March 1998. How many trusts does the Assistant Treasurer believe a farmer needs to achieve these objectives? Isn't it the case that a network of trusts such as that which Senator Heffernan has constructed has everything to do with tax avoidance and nothing to do with succession planning?

—If Senator Conroy really is prepared to stand behind what he said and the accusation that he has made against a colleague in this chamber on tax avoidance, I suggest he follow the Robert Ray principle—very simple, just walk out the door and make the accusations. We will see then, Senator, whether you are prepared to stand behind them or not. If you are not prepared to stand behind them, Senator, I do not propose to answer that question.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister agree that it is not the role of the tax system, nor is it the duty of taxpayers, to subsidise tax avoiders like Senator Heffernan? Maybe, Senator Heffernan, you want to break your duck and stand up, after 12 minutes of speaking since you became a frontbencher. On your feet, Senator Heffernan!

—I rise on a point of order. Madam President, you cannot possibly allow those imputations to go unchallenged. Senator Conroy should have been stopped before he started. That is outrageous and it is an abuse of the parliamentary system and, Madam President, I urge you to consider your options with this sort of thing.
—The imputations against the senator must be withdrawn, Senator.
—Which imputations? Tax avoidance does not have to be withdrawn. Tax evasion would, but tax avoidance does not.
—Senator Conroy, I ask you to withdraw.
—If there's any imputation, you can withdraw it.
—If there is any imputation, I withdraw.
—Unconditionally withdraw, Senator.

—Madam President, if he has withdrawn the question that he asked, there is no question to answer. I would urge Senator Conroy, before he joins his colleagues in the gutter, to recall the old Robert Ray principle. Remember that? Ten yards to courage.
—Madam President, my question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Alston.
—Where's your tax policy?
—Well, you don't have one anymore.
—Senators will cease talking to each other across the chamber. It is disorderly. I am attempting to hear what Senator Woodley has to say.

—I ask the minister: is he aware that the latest OECD survey, Agricultural protection in OECD countries 1999 , shows that Australia has the second lowest percentage of government support for farmers in any of the Western countries, at seven per cent? Does the minister agree that this lack of government support for agriculture is a significant factor in the decline in rural population and rural incomes? When the USA decides in the near future to restrict sheep meat imports from Australia and New Zealand, will this government invoke the WTO options available to it?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I do not think that is a proper construction to place on the OECD report. What it tells you is that Australian farmers are amongst the most efficient in the world and that they do not need that level of subsidy and protection. That is usually a dead end because it promotes inefficiency; all of a sudden you would find the WTO telling you to pull out the rug and then you would not cope.

answer.para: There are very complex reasons why people move from rural areas and why standards of living in some areas are declining. A large part of the problem of course was total neglect over a 13-year period. We are doing our best to redress that problem. Certainly, the latest package of announcements following on from the latest privatisation of Telstra will enable us to ensure that people do not have to move to urban areas to be able to get high speed access to the Internet, for example. A lot of small businesses will be able to get the latest information from around the world in order to run their farms, and get commodity prices, weather reports and the like. In other words, very sophisticated businesses can be run from very remote areas. That is simply one example of how we are trying to pick up the pieces from what the Labor Party managed to inflict upon the rural sector.

Rather than trying to pretend that somehow protection is the answer to their problems—which people in the bush generally do not espouse anymore, Senator Woodley, and nor does the NFF—you ought to be much more interested in trying to explore further opportunities for people in rural areas and identifying those businesses that can prosper, even though they might be exposed to competition, as long as that competition is fair. I think that remains our challenge. We do not want to see unfair competition. We do not want to see the Americans making a discriminatory announcement in relation to lamb any more than we wanted one on steel. We welcome the recent decision in relation to steel by the United States administration. We hope that we are all moving in the right direction. The right direction is not more protection; the right direction is to be very competitive and to concentrate on those skills and resources in which we have a comparative advantage.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question which does come out of the minister's answer. Minister, you did not answer the question, which is really the critical part, about whether or not the government will invoke WTO options available to it. The Deputy Prime Minister almost said he would the other night at an Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation function that I attended. Is the minister aware of Mr Tim Fischer's comments that a worst case scenario would result in a 25 per cent reduction in the export of Australian lamb to the US? I ask again, in that event, will the government invoke those WTO options? Whether or not they are protection, I do not care, but I ask you: will the government invoke them?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not recall Senator Woodley including any reference to the WTO in his first question, but it is a legitimate proposition—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am simply saying I do not recall it; I did not deny that he did.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections and there is far too much noise in the chamber.

—It is certainly a valid question, but I think we ought to wait and see what the response of the US administration is. Certainly we were heartened by the vote in relation to steel. I think we ought to simply wait and see. Once we get a decision, if it is an adverse one, then we will clearly consider all of our options. Clearly we have rights and entitlements under the WTO and we will obviously examine those closely if the need arises.

—Madam President, my question without notice is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Ellison. In the light of yesterday's High Court decision in relation to former senator-elect Heather Hill, has the government considered amending section 170 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act? Specifically, has the government considered the possibility of requiring candidates born overseas or who have been citizens of other countries to declare on the nomination form that they have taken steps to renounce that citizenship? While accepting that such a declaration would have no legal effect, is it not a fact that it would at least remind and prompt candidates to consider their obligations under the act, thus diminishing the likelihood of experiencing legal action in the future?

—Can I say to Senator Hogg that that is a very good question. This matter is still before the court; the High Court adjourned the matter until Tuesday next week. I do not want to touch on anything the High Court has said, but Senator Hogg has raised an issue which—
—We're talking about the nomination form.

—If Senator Faulkner would just keep quiet for a while, I will take this matter on board. This is a very good question and one which the government will take on board and give consideration to. This is an issue which is in the community and one which needs to be addressed.

—My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. Will the minister outline to the Senate the excellent benefits to local government, particularly councils in rural areas, which will flow from the government's revised tax reform plan?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Calvert—a distinguished member of a local authority before he came here—for his question. I appreciate Senator Calvert asking me a question about local government because, regrettably, no-one from the Labor Party will. I do not know what has happened to my shadow. Apparently she has no interest in local government.

answer.para: Local government does very well out of the tax reform package. In regional Australia, local government has done particularly well. The new tax system will remove many embedded costs that currently impinge upon local government and will allow them to operate with lower costs and with assured funding. As senators well know, general rates will be GST free, charges for water and sewerage will be GST free, regulatory and licensing charges will be GST free and fines and penalties will be GST free. The new tax system will allow councils, like businesses, to claim a full refund of all GST payable on their purchases.

The new tax system will also save all councils money on the operation of their vehicle fleets from the reduced petrol and diesel excise. This will particularly benefit councils in rural and regional, non-metropolitan Australia who will also get a diesel fuel excise cut of around 23c a litre for vehicles over 20 tonnes GVM and for passenger or goods vehicles servicing regional Australia with a GVM between 4.5 tonnes and 20 tonnes.

In addition, all councils have benefited from the reduction in interest rates over the time the Howard government has been in power. When I was last on a local authority, about nine years ago, under the Labor regime councils were paying 13, 14, 15, 16 and 17 per cent interest on their borrowings which usually are quite substantial. Nowadays, because of what the Howard government has done, councils are paying in the range of six to seven per cent. That is a huge saving for councils which is passed on to ratepayers. In addition, the good news from the sale of Telstra—which was opposed from the Labor Party—is that we have been able to make major benefits for country Australia and particularly for country councils. We have provided some $45 million for councils in rural and regional Australia to help them get online. I cannot understand why the shadow for local government, Senator Sue Mackay, actually voted against that. Why did she vote against giving an additional $45 million to councils to get online? Why did the shadow for regional services, Mrs Kernot, vote against legislation that had an enormous number of benefits particularly for people in regional Australia? It allows them to get online in telecommunications. It gives them the access to benefits that people in the Labor Party who live in the capital cities take for granted. They are not available in the country at the moment, but we intend to do something about it; we intend to provide it.

Why the shadow minister for regional services and the shadow minister for local government would oppose these sorts of things I simply cannot understand. It is beyond me that those benefits for regional Australia and for places like Tasmania are opposed by the Labor Party. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to add to two answers which I gave today. The first one was to Senator Lees. I am advised that, when the World Heritage Committee's mission visited Australia to look at the issue of Jabiluka they were given a copy of the most recent plan of management for Kakadu National Park, which specifically referred to the Newcrest mining case and the implications of that case. speech.para: I also wish to clarify my answer to the obscure question by Senator Bolkus in relation to nuclear reactors. CONFIDENTIAL
Brief Number 7.7
MARRIAGE EDUCATION AND DISTRIBUTION OF NATIONAL FAMILIES STRATEGY

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON

subdebateinfo.title: Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Legislation

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill) to a question without notice asked by Senator Bolkus today, relating to nuclear installations.

It is less the 24 hours since the environment legislation passed this place and already it is unravelling. This camel of a bill, designed by Howard's Liberals and put together by the Democrats and National Party, has already struck a fundamental flaw. The answer that Senator Hill gave straight after question time is just not good enough. With a bill of 500 clauses with 900 amendments, of which we had some four hours notice of the 500 government amendments, it is no wonder that we have already struck a loophole in the legislation. Last night and this morning, Western Australian resources minister, Colin Barnett, said that rushed legislation invariably ends up in poor legislation, and that is what we have here.

Under the previous legislation, the previous environment regime, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act—the EPIP act—would have come into play. Under that act, there would have been a national inquiry into matters such as we have raised today. But we are now in the era of the brave new environmental deregulation laws of Senator Hill and Senator Lees and because of that the EPIP legislation no longer continues to apply. That is why the opposition, in addressing the legislation before the parliament yesterday, decided to accept the new definition proposed by the government, and not only did we accept it but we also tried to amend it to expand its operation. That is why we did not try to wind it back to the definition in the ARPANSA legislation.

Let us look at the legislation that passed through the parliament yesterday. The Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] , as introduced, provided for the control of nuclear reactions. Section 21, in conjunction with the provisions of chapter 4, required assessment and approval of nuclear reactions. Nuclear reaction was defined to include `establishing or significantly modifying a nuclear installation or a facility for storing spent nuclear fuel.' The amended legislation drops the reference to `a facility for storing spent nuclear fuel.' There will no longer have to be an environmental assessment in respect of that. Nuclear installation was also defined in the primary legislation and it was amended after the deal with the Democrats. In that amendment, we have the deletion of `nuclear reactor, including critical and sub-critical assemblies', and also of `nuclear power plants'.

When we talk about `nuclear reactor', we talk about a nuclear reactor for nuclear power. That has now been excised from the legislation as well. They have also removed some of the most important civil and criminal penalties attaching to these sorts of constructions. So now have new legislation, amended after a secret deal, allowing for the construction of a nuclear power plant in this country without an environmental assessment. Let me stress that point. Under the previous regime, there would have to have been an environmental assessment under the EPIP act. Under this regime, there is no such control because Senator Hill and Senator Lees got together in a secret meeting to delete it.

In their new definition of a nuclear installation, we also have a note that says, `a nuclear waste or disposal facility could include a facility for the storing of spent nuclear fuel depending on the regulations.' We can now set up a nuclear storage plant, a nuclear waste plant. We can set that up depending on regulations. Not only have we have a wind-back but we have had a secret wind-back, one with monumental implications. As I have said before, we had a definition in the ARPANSA legislation, but that was in the context of the EPIP act applying and environmental assessment being almost inevitable under that act. We now have a situation where the minister can set up a waste dump by regulation. The minister has no power to control, through national environmental assessment, the construction of a nuclear power plant or nuclear reactor.

The minister says, `Oh, well, this is a definition that was used before.' But this is not a regime that applied before. Under this new system put in place by the Australian Democrats and the government, for instance, we can even see a devolution of authority here to state governments. Under section 25 of the legislation, where the federal minister has to consult and is to take all reasonable steps to come to an agreement with appropriate ministers in the states and territories, we could have Richard Court or Denis Burke dictating the terms of construction. This is not national leadership because we have failed in our national responsibility over the last few days. We have failed because we had 500 amendments brought in here at the last moment without adequate scrutiny—we had four hours notice! That is why we now have this vacuum.
Senator Tambling in the previous debate said, in respect of the ARPANSA legislation, that:
This legislation is not the place to try to change the ways in which proposals are assessed and proceed. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act still applies.
That, Senator Hill, is a fundamental point and Senator Tambling put it on the record. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The problem with Senator Bolkus's speech was that he wrote it before he listened to the answer and, unfortunately, if he had listened to the answer first, he would not have given it. Having listened to the answer, he did not have the creativity to write a new one and therefore he blurted out that which he assumed would meet the answer that would be given by me. He is embarrassed because the government had in fact amended its bill to reflect the amendment previously in the ARPANSA legislation, that is, the licensing authority legislation for nuclear installations. So now we have a clear complementary passage of the licensing authority, subject to the assessment under the new Commonwealth legislation that we passed in this place yesterday. So it really is difficult to understand Senator Bolkus's argument.

speech.para: Rising to my feet on this subject does give me the opportunity to thank a number of conservation groups in Australia for the support they have given for the new legislation. Apart from conservation groups, I wanted to thank ATSIC as the leading indigenous group in Australia for its support, which is appreciated. We look forward to working with indigenous Australia in the implementation of the legislation.
What did the World Wide Fund for Nature say? They said that for WWF this agreement now passed in this chamber:

. . . is the successful culmination of a decade of working for better legislation to protect threatened species and ecological communities, and four years of advocacy for better national environmental legislation.
The Humane Society International said:
We now consider this to be a piece of legislation that will deliver a greater degree of protection for Australia's precious biodiversity and fragile environments than existing legislation.
I move on to the Queensland Conservation Council. They said yesterday:

The Queensland Conservation Council today welcomed the agreement between the Federal Government and the Democrats to considerably strengthen the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill .
The Tasmanian Conservation Trust said:
The Tasmanian Conservation Trust today congratulated the Howard government on taking a great step forward for environmental legislation in Australia . . .
They further said the bill was:
. . . something conservation groups have been asking for for years now and we thank the government for it.

These are the conservation groups that were traditionally the supporters of the ALP, but of course the ALP sat on its hands for 13 years and was not prepared to give this country contemporary environmental law. It is interesting that, when questioned yesterday, Michael Lynch from the Tasmanian Conservation Trust said that `the responsibility of conservation groups was to work to improve legislation, not just to spend their time criticising.'

These are the groups that were once the supporters of Senator Bob Brown, who thought Senator Bob Brown would come into this place and deliver better environmental outcomes for them. They have obviously abandoned him as a failure, which is not surprising. We learnt yesterday that his total achievement in this place is that he succeeded in getting one amendment in one bill passed—not bad for three years work, I would have thought. When you think of the power that he has in this place, he has not saved a single tree. What a legacy of three years work. It is not surprising that the conservation groups have abandoned him as they have abandoned the ALP.

The last point I wanted to make, which I did not have the chance to make yesterday—but I sort of said it in the answer today—is that this bill is not just about the environment; it is about adopting high environmental standards but as part of sustainable development. This government wants to see our economy grow. It wants to see more jobs and better opportunities for people. It knows that, to do that, the Australian economy has to be internationally competitive. It will make its judgments under this legislation pursuant to those goals. This legislation says the environment minister must take into account economic and social consequences. We will make our decisions to the background of wanting to maintain a strong Australian economy, but we will do so whilst at the same time demanding high environmental standards. After passage of this bill in this place, after it becomes law, we will have the legal framework within which we can achieve those dual goals—something long overdue in this country. Now we have the capacity to do it we will be able to deliver the goods.

talk.start.para: —This issue of nuclear installations will be just the first of a very significant number of examples of where inadequacies, major holes and problems are found with the government's environmental legislation. The government-Democrat environmental legislation is starting to unravel already. This is riddled with holes. This environment legislation is legislative Swiss cheese. The haste of this exercise, the secret talks, the failure to let the environmental lawyers of the three major environmental organisations into the talks—that is, the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Wilderness Society and Greenpeace—and the failure to allow those organisations and their lawyers to have a look at the amendments is a good example, but not the only one, of why this bill is going to be an environmental disaster. It is not just the conservation organisations; it is the industry, it is the states, it is all of the interest groups we ought to take account of in this.

speech.para: The Democrat-sponsored guillotine to allow 105 pages of government and Democrat amendments to be dealt with in a single day has led to this situation where we have legislative Swiss cheese. This is hopeless policy making. This is negligence on the part of the Democrats particularly—negligence and stupidity writ large. The Democrats are always beating their chests about parliamentary scrutiny, but when it comes down to tintacks, when it comes down to scrutinising their own nasty little backdoor deals with the government, where are they? They turn their back on accountability.

This legislation is a reality now. The deal is done, the fix is in. But the Democrats have fouled it up—there is no doubt about that. Their constituency is outraged about the scam, the deal, with the government. They will be outraged about this nuclear installation loophole. But it is just the first of many; there will be more to come. Just wait for it, Senator Bartlett. It is going to wash right over the top of you. We do not know how many loopholes there will be in this legislation, but we intend to use the forums this parliament provides to expose them.

You have got the environmental and conservation constituency deserting Senator Lees and the Democrats. You have got the small business constituency that they care about being hit with the compliance costs of the GST and the ramshackle Democrat Irish model. At the next election, you are going to have the Democrats scrabbling around at the bottom of the barrel, looking for votes. This is the consequence of the Democrats, led by the Madame Defarge of the Senate, Senator Lees, imposing a guillotine and not allowing proper parliamentary scrutiny of an exceptionally important piece of legislation before this chamber.

talk.start.para: —I call Senator Crane.
—I defer to Senator Bartlett.
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: that is fine, but the preferred call of the opposition should be the next speaker.
—That is what I intend to do. I call Senator Bartlett.

—We have heard just now lots of comments about Swiss cheese. The main holes and problems are not with the legislation but are obviously with Senator Bolkus's and Senator Faulkner's understanding of it. That is probably understandable, because the ALP have not shown much interest or commitment to the environment for some time now, and so they have not really made much of an attempt or effort to try to keep abreast of the very complex and important issues that are involved in environmental legislation.

speech.para: It is good to see them come on board now, at this late stage. Sure, they are driven by political opportunity rather than commitment to the issue, but at least the political opportunity has given them the impetus to think, `We had better look at this environment thing again; we might have a bit of a wedge that we can drive here.' They are probably in a situation where they can now spell `environment' again, which is a good start. Perhaps, as part of this process and their efforts to scrutinise what the Democrats have achieved with this, they will possibly even now give some policy commitments as well—some actual indications of what they would do in government. That would be welcome. It would be yet one more positive thing to come out of the agreement that the Democrats have managed to reach.

I am certainly quite happy for the Democrats to beat their chests about this. I have spent a lot of time over many years trying to promote advancing the environment. I am very keen to have the opportunity to be part of advancing environmental protection.
Senator Brown interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown once again is accusing the Tasmanian Conservation Trust of staffing the chainsaws along with the Democrats, and I guess that is for them to answer, if he wants to continue to abuse the conservation groups of his own home state. He quite often likes to call the Democrats `poodles'—and it does not worry me; I am quite fond of animals, as people know, and so I have no problem being called a poodle or a puppy; I prefer rottweilers to poodles, but any animal is nice. But he certainly does a lot of yapping for somebody who likes to call other people poodles.

speech.para: What is most important, obvious and blatant about the lack of understanding behind the abuse that the ALP has put forward in relation to this legislation and in response to issues that were raised in question time is the need to once again look at what the situation is now, under existing law. The Democrats, as I have said repeatedly and will continue to say, do not in any way suggest that the environment legislation that was passed in this chamber is the perfect environment legislation. We have quite clearly pointed out that there are still many areas where work needs to be done, and we will be fighting hard to ensure that there is future effort. With the new-found interest of the Labor Party and Senator Conroy, that well-known greenie in environmental issues, I am sure they will join us in improving this legislation even further.

But Senator Bolkus has missed the key point of what this legislation does. He goes on about the problem of things being in regulations. On top of the expansion of Commonwealth powers that we have achieved in this legislation, we have now enabled a mechanism for Commonwealth powers to be expanded further in the future through regulation. Wherever an issue of importance arises the government can in a simple way act quickly at federal level to expand its powers. Certainly, the parliament cannot force the government to act other than through political pressure, but it gives an extra mechanism for that power to be broadened even more widely than is currently the case under the new legislation that was passed yesterday.

If the ALP want to resort to the complete misinformation, misrepresentation and total fabrication that Senator Brown continues to go on with in the media and in this place, that somehow or other this bill—
Senator Brown interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He is again accusing the Tasmanian conservation movement of selling out on Tasmania's forests.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy President. I do not mind how much there is of this misrepresentation, but I ask people to read the Hansard . I am accusing the Democrats of selling out on the Tasmanian forests—which of course they are.
—There is no point of order. It is purely a debating point.

—Senator Brown continues to make the accusations that, with this bill, Fraser Island would be mined and the Franklin flooded. Of course, this bill actually expands Commonwealth powers and expands protection under world heritage. The only environmental issue that the Labor Party has joined the Democrats on is in relation to Jabiluka. That that is happening now, in a world heritage area under existing legislation, shows how little protection there is for world heritage areas under the law as it stands now. This is why it is so important that what the Democrats have achieved has expanded world heritage protection and expanded the ability not just for the government to protect the environment but for the parliament and other people in the Australian community to protect the environment. And that is why it is so significant. (Time expired)

—In the less than two minutes that are left, I want to emphasise that Senator Tambling, the minister involved in the ARPANSA legislation, said that the ARPANSA legislation was not the place to deal with the issue of the form of environmental assessments in relation to nuclear facilities. The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act still applies, and it can be expected that any substantial proposal will invoke the procedures under this act. We asked for a needs assessment. The Democrats supported us in that motion and that was denied, 33 votes to 32. Basically, we said it was needed, it was voted down by the government, and what we have now is a situation where we do not have it.

speech.para: We assumed that it would be included in the environmental impact assessment act. We assumed that we might have the numbers to make sure that it was included in that act. It was not, and now we have the potential of a Democrats nuclear installation. I am sure the people at Lucas Heights or anywhere else in Australia will remember what the Democrats have done. We tried, the motion was lost, and the minister said, `Don't worry; put it in the environmental impact assessment bill.' It did not happen. It has not happened and, as Senator Faulkner says, from now on we are going to find more and more of these slips, because it was pushed through with such undue haste.

There is a huge amount of concern in the community about the details and about the ramifications of this bill. Some might be better than we expect. However, unfortunately, I expect that the slips are going to be worse than any benefits and that, in time, we will find out the costs of the unnecessarily undue haste with which this most important bill was dealt.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

debate.para: Senator HEFFERNAN (New South Wales—Parliamentary Secretary to Cabinet) (3.30 p.m.)—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday I was accused of not declaring a $2 million property, Cooba. Cooba Pty Ltd is a property of my cousin Celsa Cusack. It is her family property at Junee. Even though Labor, who assume that every farmer that has a family trust is a crook, will not understand, people in the bush pride themselves on being good neighbours. The only benefit I have received from the Cusack's property is the pleasure of doing something for nothing—of assisting a family whose grandfather was crippled when a load of bagged oats fell on him and broke his back and both hips; a family whose mother was widowed and left with six children under the age of 15; a family whose sister was murdered in March of 1995.

interjection.para: In 1970, I was proud and delighted when asked by my uncle, Joe Paslow, the crippled father of Celsa Cusack, to be a director of his company. He died in August 1977. Following the tragic death of Mrs Cusack's husband, John, in October 1977, when he had a young family of six, I did assist her. In the 22 years since, her children have long grown up and taken full responsibility and control of their family farming interests.

I did not disclose a directorship or interest in these companies because it was my understanding that I had ceased to be a director or shareholder well before entering the Senate. It was only yesterday afternoon that Mrs Celsa Cusack advised that I was still a director and shareholder. Perhaps only the grubby operatives of the Labor Party will not understand why Mrs Cusack, whose four-year nightmare following the brutal murder of her daughter in 1995—a family tragedy not lessened by the gaoling for life of the murderer in February of this year—might have overlooked her accountant's advice to tell me when I entered the Senate that my understanding that I had ceased to be a director and shareholder was inaccurate. Yesterday, I resigned as a director and gave instructions that my few shares be disposed of forthwith by gifting them to her family. At no stage have I ever received a benefit from the Cooba Pastoral Company Pty Ltd. I apologise to the Senate for not disclosing my directorship of Mrs Cusack's family company and my one share, valued at $1, in Sestial Pty Ltd—the trustee company that runs my family farm.

I think Mr Beazley, who seeks to be seen by Australians as a universally nice bloke, should write an apology to the Cusack family for dredging up all of these traumatic memories because Senator Robert Ray and Senator Faulkner, whom nobody would describe as nice, will not.

Labor made three other allegations yesterday. With respect to the allegation that I did not declare land at Balranald, that is simply untrue. There is one holding covering both parts of the Shire of Hay and Shire of Balranald called Little Lake. With respect to Sestial Pty Ltd, I advised the Register of Senators' Interests on 15 January 1999 that I was a director. In addition, I disclosed my directorship and shareholding in Sestial to the Prime Minister following my appointment as parliamentary secretary. Lest there be any misunderstanding, I again point out that Sestial Pty Ltd is the trustee company that controls the family trust that runs my farm. I have at all times disclosed the existence of the family trust. The fact that I am a farmer and my family owns various properties is a matter of public record.

Lastly, Labor has questioned whether my duties as Parliamentary Secretary to the Cabinet were inconsistent with or have been compromised in some way by my directorships or interests in various private family companies. I have been scrupulous in ensuring that, where any matters such as taxation law or a similar issue have been in the process of being dealt with by cabinet, I have declared an interest.

At no stage have I ever sought to improperly use my position for personal advantage. I did not enter the Senate to make money. My family and I have always conducted our affairs in an ethical manner. There is not the slightest substance to any suggestion that I have misused my position for personal gain. I feel very sorry for the people who voted Labor at the last election. They are represented in this place by people who have nothing to offer as an alternative government, no plan for their future other than personal vilification—

talk.start.para: —Senator Heffernan, this is getting into debating points.

—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. We have listened to a great deal of Senator Heffernan and his personal explanation, but whether he feels sorry or not for people and how they voted at the last election that, as you know, Madam Deputy President, is not a matter that is relevant to any personal explanation. If that is all he has to say, he should be sat down.
—Senator Heffernan, if you have further points you wish to make, keep the politics out.

—The Cusack family is a great example of a gritty farming family. Their two sons, John and Richard, still continue to carry on the tradition on the family farm through the entire trauma I have disclosed. I am proud to have been associated with them and I am ashamed of some of the people who sit opposite. In relation to the three companies raised by Senator Cook this afternoon, these are companies that are asset holding and do not trade.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering government amendments Nos 1 to 14 on sheet 238, and government amendments 7, 8, 9, 12, 14 and 22 on sheet EF239. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.
—I was hoping that possibly the minister might have an answer to some of the questions I asked a little earlier about flavoured milk and additives.

speech.para: Senator Kemp interjecting—

talk.start.para: —No, you might have given them an apology. I had other business.
—In other words, you are waiting for Senator Cook again. Thanks for the filler, Senator Conroy.

speech.para: Senator Murphy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I have been fairly busy today, Senator Murphy. The point I was making is that under the wholesale sales tax system, chocolate Qik is exempt and strawberry Qik cops 12 per cent.
—Is that just to do with the price of strawberries?
—This is the question I was asked by your colleague.
—Would we assist you by leaving, Senator?
—Yes, you would, actually. Murphy, too, please, Robert. Get him out as well.
—Order, Minister!

—He broke the deal. He's still here. Robert Ray always claims that the one thing you can rely on is that he sticks to a deal. He asked, `Would we assist by leaving?' He left, and he does not ever refer to himself in the third person plural.
—Minister, this has no relevance to the question asked.

—I went on to say that, under the GST, chocolate Qik and strawberry Qik are GST free. The government has removed the anomaly. Flavoured milk of all flavours will be taxable, Senator. Find another filler for him.

—My question was to do with the fact that you have defined flavourings as GST free and milk as GST free. I understand that in other cases where you combine a GST item and a non-GST item it attracts GST. I am trying to gain an understanding why two non-GST items can be combined and end up with GST.
—It is quite common, Senator. I think you are confusing the original rule of a GST free product combined with a product subject to GST, but there is not a rule of the nature that you then adduced.
—So it's whatever you and the Democrats say?

—Essentially, it is whatever the Senate decides. If you want to go back to the old Labor position of having strawberry Qik at 12 per cent and chocolate Qik exempt, you do that, but I do not think people think it is sensible. The community out there thinks we have removed an anomaly and will prob ably welcome this. I think that covers the GST Qik flavouring issue. I see Senator George Campbell has come back to provide some further fillers.

—I want to make it absolutely clear that there is no rationale—it is just whatever has been decided between the Democrats and you. When the court challenges start flowing about what is in and what is not, the Taxation Office and the judges will look to the debate in the chamber for some guidance as to what it is that constitutes the reasoning behind the tax law. I know it was probably a mistake, but I was hoping that you might be able to clarify it.

speech.para: I refer to the Prime Minister's letter about the 96 per cent issue, which says that `products consisting of milk not less than 95 per cent by volume will be GST free'. I want to make sure there is not a contradictory situation with flavoured milk. I presume that a product consisting of milk not less than 95 per cent would be flavoured milk. If flavoured milk had 96 per cent, where would we be then?

talk.start.para: —If it is in ready-to-drink form, the product is taxable. Seeing that Senator George Campbell has come into the chamber, I want to deal with the carob issue that you raised. I actually was not aware of this product.
—It's a chocolate substitute.

—I have since become aware of that. That was Senator Campbell's contribution to the sum of human knowledge. You may have eating habits which are not similar to mine, and that is fair enough; I make no judgment on that. If it is marketed as a confectionery, it will be taxable; if it is marketed as an additive for milk, it will be GST free.

—While we are on the subject of healthy foods, I also ask the minister about the exclusion of unprocessed grains, cereals and sugar cane, et cetera, which is covered in 1.11 in the explanatory memorandum. It says:

speech.para: This will ensure that grains sold as seed or sold for further processing or treatment will be subject to GST.

What happens in circumstances where these unprocessed grains or cereals are sold through health food stores, which is a common practice. Are they GSTable if they are sold through those stores, or are they GST free?

talk.start.para: —Senator, I will look—as I always do—very carefully at your question and, if you will bear with me, I will provide you some advice in a short moment of time.
—Thank you for that, Minister. Did I get an answer to my question on bagels?
—I think I did give you an answer.
—Is it all form of bagels?
—I think you asked whether a bagel with a blueberry ingredient is GST free. I am not quite sure what the cost of a bagel is, but I am advised that bagels with a blueberry ingredient are GST free.

—I asked in relation to bagels and to bagels which had blueberries. But I also have a question on the list of breads that is contained in the explanatory memorandum. A range of breads are mentioned—pita bread, lebanese bread, lavash bread—but it does not mention bagels. I know you come from Victoria, so I am not surprised that you may not be aware of it, but bagels are a very popular form of bread in Sydney. I want to make sure that bagels are included in the list.

—Senator, if it has a sweet filling or coating, it is going to be GST free. I notice your love of bagels, Senator. I do not want you to suggest or think that Victorians do not have their fair share of bagels. I am sure this is a bakery product which is popular in my state. In fact, I can buy bagels at my local shop.
—You obviously don't.
—I do not, but my wife does.
—I want to talk about milk for a moment. You have defined milk and soy milk. Does coconut milk fall into any of those categories?
—Again, these are a range of products that I am not acutely familiar with, but my understanding is that they do not.
—Is there an explanation? Are we discriminating against coconuts perhaps?
—Are coconuts GST free? They are a fresh fruit—or a fresh vegetable.
—They are GST free, Senator. To be quite frank, I used to think it was rather pleasant when Senator Cook was not in the chamber, but—
—Minister, would you please be relevant.
—I was just trying to urge Senator Cook—
—Would you like to answer the question and stop worrying about who is in the chamber.
—I have just answered the question. Madam Chair, I am delighted at the authority you are showing, and if you can show it on the other side, too, it would just be fantastic.
—I do not need that reflection, thank you.
—I do not know why the Labor Party is in favour of dearer food. GST-free food should be cheaper, and I am astonished, to be quite frank, that the Labor Party seems to object to this.
—Coconuts are GST free, and coconut milk is not. At what point in the drinking of it do you charge a GST—as they poke the holes in?
—When it falls on your head but not on the ground.
—Order! Can I ask people to curb their mirth, please, especially the galleries. Minister, do you have an answer?
—Senator, I have a tax ruling, I think. The Treasury has consulted, and coconut milk is GST free.
—That is a change from where we were a minute ago. I am particularly interested in soy milk, because there has been some argument about whether soy should be allowed to be referred to as milk.
—We picked up the current case law on how soy milk is defined, Senator.

—So if you wanted to produce another product and tack the name `milk' on the end—like, say, a pumpkin milk, and you can get a milky substance out of pumpkins—and you wanted to market something like that, is it in or out for the purposes of GST?

—That sort of issue would be a matter for the tax office, as it always is when a new product is brought forward. When a new product is brought forward, there may be a submission made to the tax office and the tax office would give a ruling on it.
—What about goat's milk?
—Goat's milk is GST free.

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I have not finished, Senator.
—Senator Conroy, please resume your seat.
—This debate on food is an interesting one, but I think the point needs to be made that as a result of the amendments which, as we know—

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I think you have to recognise that GST-free food should fall in price. Whatever arguments you may wish to adduce, Senator, the fact of the matter is—as the Treasurer has pointed out—that there should be some falls in prices. I think that can easily be claimed as a plus, and I am amazed that the Labor Party seems to be opposed to it.

—I would think that even Senator Kemp would concede that there are compliance costs involved. One of the issues about this particular package is the extra compliance costs, which are substantial. You have had Mark Paterson of ACCI, a noted supporter of the GST, indicate that the compliance cost burden is a problem. You have ATAX, our country's leading compliance specialists; you have the tax institute; you have Ray Regan—not a favourite of yours, Senator Kemp—all talk about the compliance cost burden that has been put on to many more businesses. You are asserting that any savings from what could be described as the `embedded taxes' will be greater than the compliance costs when you make that statement. It is not a statement you can make with any confidence whatsoever; it is just one of your many, many assertions without foundation. That is just to respond to that. Do we have another ruling—a quick, instantaneous ruling?
—No, you're right, keep going.
—Are you okay over there? Is Blair available regularly?
—Order! Senator Conroy, would you please be relevant?
—I understand that Senator Sherry raised some questions about the definition of `hot' in relation to food. I was wondering if we had any answers?

—Madam Chair, with your permission, I would like to add to the milk debate. Senator Conroy, you have made me somewhat hysterical at the back here—and forgive me, Madam Chair, for my amusement. Of course, there is an underlying seriousness in your questions and there needs to be an underlying seriousness in the answers. The first point is that when you make 80 per cent of household goods GST free for equity reasons, you are going to end up with some definitional prob lems. I think you had two directions to your remarks. The first is the complexity issue. From everything that we know about international practice in this area, the complexity issue is vastly overstated; the compliance issue is vastly overstated. All this stuff about nightmares is just so much political hooey and, as you know, that is a line I have stuck to consistently for months and months. I do not think it is that difficult, in terms of compliance costs, to determine which carries GST and which do not.

speech.para: The more serious issue I thought you were driving at was the definitional issue, and that occasioned some mirth. As you know, I have lived in a number of countries and had experience of many places. I am aware that it is not just cow's milk, sheep's milk and goat's milk that people drink but yak's milk, llama's milk—all sorts of milk. I think behind your view was the question of what milk might end up being GSTable as opposed to GST free. As someone who has been promoting this course of milk being GST free, my expectation is that the ruling would be very wide and that milk would include any milk that is fit for human consumption. I think the definition approaches that. Within the amendment is the fact that the GST-free category commences once food is fit for human consumption. I do not think milk is defined in the dictionary, but it is surely defined elsewhere in Australian law, under food standards or whatever. So as someone who is, if you like, supportive of the amendment, I am suggesting to you that I would seek that yak's milk, goat's milk or whatever other milk be widely acceptable.

talk.start.para: —If there are any debates in the future over this issue in the courts, they will look to the words and their intent in the Senate, so I appreciate that. My question on the definitional aspects is probably more that soy is a bean. Just because you produce it and it might be coloured white—it could be coloured anything that you might colour it—you can call it milk. So what happens if you produce another product, another vegetable, that produces a liquid that is then called milk simply to get it into the wide definition? It is fit for human consumption so it falls into that category. Just because I manufacture it and call it milk, where do you go then? What happens then? I am seeking guidance.

—Senator, soy and rice milk are defined, as I understand it, under the current wholesale sales tax law. So I do not think this is a dramatic change that you are promoting. As I said, if there are new products brought on it is a matter for tax office ruling. I think that it is probably worth putting on the record that there is an attempt here to blow the compliance issue out of all proportion. The reality is that most classifications of products will be done by the manufacturer of the product, and the number of manufacturers is a relatively small proportion of the total taxpayer population. The manufacturers, of course, have the best knowledge of their products and if they have any doubt—and this is the point I made—they can go and seek guidance from the ATO.

speech.para: When a small business buys a product, they will know from the invoice whether it is GST free or taxable. The small business will be able to sell the item GST free if they bought it GST free, provided they do not substantially alter its condition. Small businesses that sell prepared meals will generally sell a small range, much of which will have a very obvious classification. In addition, most small businesses, if they need guidance, will need guidance only once and they can apply that in each subsequent period. As we move to a new tax system of course there will be some new things that people have to do—some new procedures to follow, a new way of reporting and, of course, a new way in which we tax products. That is going to require a major education campaign by the tax office to make sure that people in small businesses are fully across the requirements, and this is exactly what the government proposes to do.

The government recognises the compliance issue. The government clearly understands that we must take every step to make sure that businesses are properly and accurately informed about the requirements under the new tax law. But we need to keep it in perspective, and it does concern me that some of the comments seem to be somewhat over blown. On the compliance issue there is, of course, a RIS which has been distributed with the bills and distributed to the chamber which outlines the net recurrent costs of compliance. So I make the point that compliance issues are important, and that is why the government seeks to address them in a most comprehensive manner, but at the same time we should not attempt to overstate them.

talk.start.para: —There are a number of matters I want to raise on this issue of food. Firstly, in the explanatory memorandum, in the final paragraph of page 1, it says:

speech.para: In addition, there will be some administrative costs for a business that has to account for GST on only some of its supplies.

We have had a considerable discussion about compliance costs for small business and the additional cost because of the food exemption. I do not want to overstate that, but what I would point out to the chamber is that the phrase `some administrative costs' is a clear understatement of the additional costs of compliance for small business of this food exemption. I would like to know what are the estimated additional administrative costs for the food exemption.

Also, looking at the input taxing of school tuckshops and canteens, it says in the explanatory memorandum that tuckshops and canteens run by a non-profit body such as a parents and citizens association or a parents and friends association—I am sure everyone is aware of the factual situation—will be GST free. But what is the difference between a tuckshop and a canteen being run by a non-profit body and one run by a contractor? There are quite a number of catering companies that run tuckshops and canteens on school premises. It is an identical business, but they are not free of the GST.

Fresh fruit and vegetables from a primary producer will be GST free. But it says that the exclusion for live animals ensures that live cows, sheep, pigs and poultry are not food. However, live crustaceans and molluscs—lobsters, oysters and crabs—will be GST free. I just want to point out here the difficulty for farmers. Many farmers on the north-west coast of Tasmania have mixed farms: they grow fresh fruit and vegetables but they also are engaged in other primary production. This certainly adds to the difficulties that farmers on the north-west coast of Tasmania will experience. My colleague Senator Campbell has raised the issue of what is rotten food, whether meat or vegetables. That seems to me to be an obvious way that the definitions of meat and vegetables can be twisted. We have asked for a definition of what is hot and what is not.

Also, I notice on page 9 of the explanatory memorandum that the tables and chairs set up on the sidewalk as part of a cafe would fall within the definition of premises. However, seats at a bus stop outside a takeaway outlet would not be premises. I can confidently predict an explosion in bus stop seats near takeaways. That again would be an obvious way to minimise GST obligations.

talk.start.para: —Come on!

—You might think it sounds stupid, Senator McGauran, but we have had example after example from no less a person than the Treasurer, Mr Costello, highlighting these sorts of absurdities as they are practised in other countries that have a GST with food exempted.
—That was then.
—I bet you there will be some after this little deal goes through. We have got the issue of what is hot and what is not. Non-heated takeaway food—
—It is cold.

—Of course it is cold, but what is to stop people taking it home and reheating it? There is a price advantage to the seller in doing that. What has even happened in some other countries is that a microwave is installed on legally separate premises and not on the premises of the seller. You could actually have the seller subcontracting as a business next door a microwave processing centre to heat the food. They would get away with it, I think, quite legally. This has happened in other countries.

speech.para: I would like to turn to the detail of the amendments. I did ask about the definition of premises where it refers to a boundary or limit. When you go to the footy—certainly in Tasmania, where we do not have the great grandstands and the clearly delineated boundaries around the football ground—it is not clear what is the boundary. You would need to pull a map out to identify what is the boundary of the football ground, the showground, the garden, the amusement park or similar area because in some cases there is not a clear boundary or clear limit. That seems to me to be an obvious way of evading the GST.

Also, is cream GST free? I am looking at the definition of milk products. It says that milk, skimmed milk or buttermilk—whether liquid, powdered, concentrated or condensed—casein and whey powder or whey paste are milk products. It does not seem to me that cream fits in there anywhere. I would like a clarification of that. The difficulties of this food exemption just go on and on. This is not the only reason we oppose a GST; there are other reasons, and my colleagues and I have put them on the record. I do not intend to go into them now, but I would like answers to the specific issues I have raised. There are many more problems with this particular legislation. What we have here is the Democrats on main street—the Democrats have driven onto main street.

I really did take exception to the comments of Senator Lees, the Leader of the Democrats. I do not want to misquote her, but I think she said words to the effect that they had achieved more in 13 hours of negotiations than they had with the Labor government in 13 years. I recall her saying that. I see the government advisers nodding, so I believe that is an accurate reflection of what she said. Senator Lees is not in the chamber, again. She helped hatch this little deal with the Liberals. She should be in here, along with Senator Murray, defending and explaining these issues that my colleagues and I have been raising. But she is not here, and I think that is a pity. We all know that, from time to time, we cannot all be in the chamber, but Senator Lees is involved in these negotiations and she should be in here explaining these issues. Unfortunately she is not.

Senator Lees claims that she got more out of the Liberals in 13 hours than she got from us in 13 years. I do not believe the record will show that. What really worries me about that statement is that what Senator Lees and five-sevenths of her Democrat colleagues have done in 13 hours—Senator Lees is entering the chamber—is create for lower and middle income Australians and for small business a potentially disastrous position.

One of the reasons—and Senator Harradine, to his credit, identified this—Labor and Senator Harradine would not support a GST is that the compensation measures can be taken away at some future date. You only have to look at the comments of the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett. I bet we will have the Liberals—Mr Kennett, Mr Costello and the Prime Minister—all attempting to remove this food exemption in coming years. The Liberals have jumped at this deal with the Democrats because they get a GST into Australia, and their strategy will be to get food out at some future date. The compensation to lower and middle income earners will ultimately be eroded. If the budget goes into deficit or if the surplus declines it will not be higher income earners who will have to pay tax increases or suffer service reductions; it will be lower and middle income earners.

We have the Democrats on main street. I think their attempts to drive on main street are very unfortunate. We have the Democrats driving along in their solar powered bus reading the map to main street. You have Senator Lees at the wheel. Next to her you have Senator Stott Despoiler trying to grab the wheel. You have Senator Murray trying to drive from the back seat. They are trying to find main street in this 13 hours and Senator Lees is complaining about the dreadful pressure she is under in this 13 hours of negotiation. What the Democrats have done with respect to this and other matters in the package really does concern me.

I would like answers to the specific matters that I have raised. They are by no means the only concerns we have about the problems of partial food exemption. I note that Senator Knowles in her earlier contribution referred to us as being `petty nitpickers'. But quite frankly most of the examples and issues that my colleagues and I have raised are ones that Senator Ferguson—I am glad he is back in the Senate again—and his colleagues referred to in their own report.

talk.start.para: —You are a major nitpicker.
—They are major nitpicking but they are also very similar to the sorts of criticisms we have been making. I am going to come back very briefly to this report and again refer to some of the examples.
—What report was that?

—This is the report of the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System, and the issue of food was a major issue before the committee. The Liberal senators signed off only a few weeks ago on the report. On page 333 they went to considerable detail on this issue of food. In fact, much of the thrust of the questions from Senator Ferguson and his colleagues went to the issue of not exempting food. The major component of their report relates to food. The Liberal senators went into considerable detail about why food should be in the GST. They actually had a reference to the irresponsibility of the Democrat position. The position the Liberals are speaking in favour of today, as a result of their deal with the Democrats, was an irresponsible position only a few weeks ago. The report says:

speech.para: One disappointing aspect of the debate has been the propensity of the Democrats to claim the support of people whose views do not actually support them.

The Liberal senators, including Senator Ferguson, go on to highlight the division in the Democrats over the crucial question of how much food should be exempt. Senator Lees is condemned for supporting a narrow definition which excludes restaurants and for contradicting her own economics spokesperson, Senator Murray, who favours a wider definition including restaurants. The report goes on—the problems for small farmers, the problems for small business generally and the problems referred to by the National Farmers Federation. For example, the decision not to tax basic food but to tax restaurant meals and takeaways `adds mind-numbing complexity to the tax system', according to the National Farmers Federation submission to the Senate select committee.

I have to say we have not heard too much from the NFF on this issue; we haven't heard a lot. On this issue the NFF are really just toeing the government line. They are absolute lackeys for the government on this issue. We have not heard them repeat this sort of criticism since this Liberal-Democrats deal was struck. It just goes on, and of course Mr Howard himself repeated these criticisms. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Sherry is weeping into his cups, pretending to show some concern for small business. I would have to say, Senator, that that fits ill in a Labor Party senator's mouth.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It fits ill in a Labor Party senator's mouth, let me say, to show concern for small business. One of the things that small business certainly wanted was some reform of the unfair dismissals law, which of course you opposed and you continue to oppose—so much for you going around worrying about small business when you are run by the trade unions and the George Campbells of this world. How much concern did George Campbell show for small business?

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy and Senator Campbell! Order!

—Thank you for reminding me. Senator Sherry gets up and weeps for small business. Senator George Campbell, who is in the chamber, is famous for one thing. It was very nicely conceptualised by former Labor Prime Minister Keating, who—after one of George Campbell's outrageous demands on business as a leader of a trade union—said that as a result of his efforts Senator Campbell `has 100,000 dead men hanging around his neck'.

speech.para: Senator George Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is what you did for small business, Senator Campbell. So I think everyone should remember, when Senator Campbell gets up here and expresses great concern about small business, that very famous quote by Mr Keating.
—Boring.

—You might find it boring, Senator, but every time you get up and talk about business we will remind you. Let me assure you: you will be reminded time and time again, because that is the one thing you are remembered for. Again, Senator Sherry got up and sort of wept over huge concerns about what he saw as boundary line issues. That is what Senator Sherry said: he was worried about complexity. Well, Senator, I have already mentioned some problems with the Labor Party's preferred system, the wholesale sales tax system. If we are talking about complexities, let us look at the incredible complexities which occur under your system.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I have a point of order and it does go to relevance. We are dealing with food amendments in respect of a GST and the questions that I posed directly related to that. They are the questions the minister should be addressing at this stage in the committee. It is about relevance.
—Minister, I think that it would be wise to come back to the issue in hand. You have been given a fair hearing; I think I would rule that.

—On the point of order as to relevance, Mr Temporary Chairman: I think that you have of course shown considerable tolerance in rulings to allow Senator Sherry to range far and wide into issues that are primarily the concern of the Democrats.
—I didn't, actually.
—There is no point of order—if you raised one.

—Look at some of the issues that we have to grapple with in the current tax system—toothpaste is taxable but toothbrushes are exempt. Why? I don't know. Has anyone explained that to us? No, no-one knows. Books, pamphlets, leaflets and magazines are exempt but atlases are taxed at 12 per cent. Why is that? I don't know. This is your preferred system. State libraries, museums and art galleries are exempt if they are in a capital city—that is the advice I have received—but are taxable if they are in regional centres. In other words, they are exempt from sales tax if they are in a capital city. Wedding rings are exempt. Engagement rings are taxed at 32 per cent. What a great system! Why? I don't know why. Senator, that is your system.
—It's your system.
—No, that's your system. We are trying to change this.
—It's your system.
—It's your system and we are trying to change it. Senator Sherry has just got married. Why, Senator Sherry, are wedding rings exempt but engagement rings are taxed at 32 per cent?
—I only bought the wedding ring. I didn't buy the engagement ring, if that is the answer.
—There we are—that is the answer.
—Senator Sherry, you tax avoider! You're miserable!
—Senator Conroy! Order!
—All I am saying is that Senator Sherry has revealed what a cheapskate he really is.
—Order! Senator Kemp! I think that everyone can get back to the point of the questions.

—Thank you. A Learjet is exempt. A luxury yacht—Senator Cook has come into the chamber—is taxed at 22 per cent and a luxury car at 45 per cent. Why the difference? I don't know. But this is the Labor Party's preferred tax system. Dishwashers, microwave ovens and air conditioners are 12 per cent. TVs, radios and videos are 32 per cent. Why? No-one knows. But this is the tax system which Senator Sherry is a really strong supporter of. Senator Sherry, you are truly Australia's greatest supporter of the wholesale sales tax system. No other country in the world wants to adopt this system; no other country wants to adopt your wholesale sales tax. In fact, I think only five countries, including Botswana, have a system which is remotely similar to ours. Funny, it is so good but no other countries want to do it. It is an amazing thing.
—Botswana is a country that is actually booming.

—If you like Botswana, you go to it. I do not see people pouring into Botswana, but I may be wrong. Senator Sherry was concerned about farmers. The first of the issues he raised related to farmers. The ATO estimates that some 84 per cent of farmers will only sell taxable items. The other 16 per cent will face additional compliance costs, that is correct. This has been factored into the estimate, which is covered in the RIS.
—Do the farmers know that?
—Senator, have you read the RIS?
—Yes, I have.
—We've read them a couple of times, but they still don't make any sense.

—Nothing makes any sense to you, Senator. Please get up and explain to us your preferred wholesale sales tax. No-one can explain it away, because it is inexplicable. It is a mess. You are out defending it and that is a disgrace.

speech.para: Recurrent compliance costs are estimated at some $240 per firm. Of course, some businesses will simply need to activate a GST module on their existing accounting software.
