Senator Colston is not with us tonight, but in his role as chair of various committees he has shown us that he has a very good grasp of standing orders and details of procedures. I think all of us wish him well in the future.

To Karen Synon, I am sorry, but I have not had the opportunity to work with you very much. Unfortunately, you have been here for only a short period of time, but I wish you well. Senator Synon was only the third female Liberal senator from Victoria. She was also the youngest senator to represent the Liberal Party in Victoria. You have shown a real commitment in human rights and issues such as, for example, your membership of Amnesty International. I wish you well in whatever you choose to do.

Senator David MacGibbon has had a long career and has served his state very well. He distinguished himself when he crossed the floor and voted for the EEO legislation. He was chair of the defence subcommittee and undertook that job with eagerness. Indeed, defence is perhaps the issue for which we know him best. Senator MacGibbon has also had a significant role and interest in the future of Bougainville and is highly commended by my colleague Senator Bourne.
We wish all of those retiring senators well and look forward to seeing a couple of them back, as long as it is not at the expense of a Democrat.

talk.start.para: —At this time we are faced with the fact that we are going to lose a number of our colleagues. That is an inevitable fact of life in politics and we all accept it, but Sandy Macdonald and Bill O'Chee are more than colleagues to me; they are friends. You cannot spend nine years and six years respectively with these people without becoming warm friends and enjoying their warm friendship. I would first like to mention the contribution of other senators before coming to these special representatives of the National Party and I will do that in order of seniority.

speech.para: Mal Colston was elected in 1975 from Queensland and I want to say that he is lucky to have his family standing by him in such difficult times. They have been loyal to him in the face of considerable opposition and I think that, if a man can say that he has got his family behind him, then he is successful in that way. I treat people the way that I find them and I have always found Mal Colston to be a decent person. I wish him well with his health problems and hope that he does have a long retirement.

Dee Margetts was elected to the Senate in 1993, where she held the balance of power with Christabelle Chamarette. She has taken particular interest in issues of international agreements, nuclear disarmament and green economics. Like Jo Valentine and Christabelle Chamarette, Dee has been a vigorous contributor on everything and she has certainly got her money's worth, and her voters have got their money's worth, if time and debate can be equated to good representation. Dee, you are totally opposite from the way we think and we could not be further apart; we are 180 degrees apart on everything, I suppose—but I do enjoy your company and I wish you well.

David MacGibbon, Liberal Senator, was returned in 1978, and I suppose his best years in politics were when we were in opposition and he was the shadow spokesman for Customs, veterans' affairs, and defence science and personnel. He has always had a very special interest in defence issues, such as National Service, Coastwatch and purchasing of defence equipment. I think one of his major achievements—he probably did not get a lot of profile on it—was that he took an active interest in brokering an agreement for peace for the nine-year war in Bougainville. For that, I think he should be commended.

Karen Synon, Liberal Senator for Victoria—well, politics has not dealt you a very good hand. But we go into this with our eyes open and it is a very difficult situation. I know that you must be tremendously disappointed. You never got a chance to display what you could have done, but there is always state politics and there is always another chance around the corner. I know that you could get very embittered about the way in which you have been treated, but bitterness never gets you very far and I wish you the best of luck.

Margaret Reynolds came into parliament with me in 1983. We both came down here together. Margaret is a representative of the Left and I suppose that we do not have a lot of politics in common, but no-one could say that Margaret is not a very pleasant person. She has been a good representative for the people in North Queensland, particularly in her interest in Aboriginal affairs. She was also the minister for local government. She now retires and she tells me that she will be spending some time in the state that she was born, Tasmania, in Launceston, and some time in Queensland. I say to you and your husband, I wish you a long and happy retirement and may you continue your interest out of politics in the things that you have been passionate about.

I come to my close colleagues now, Senators Bill O'Chee and Sandy Macdonald. The National Party is a small party without organised factions. That leads to strong friendships. We take a great personal interest in each other's progress, hardships and triumphs. Tonight is a particularly difficult time for me, as National Party Senate Leader, to formally say goodbye or at least au revoir in this chamber to my two colleagues. Both Bill and Sandy are young men with young families. Both have become fathers this year. It is a great joy to see their babies around parliament. It brings home so clearly why we try to do our best in this chamber to make good laws for the future.

Both Bill and Sandy potentially had many years of a parliamentary career ahead of them. Today we farewell them and pay tribute to their contributions to date. The National Party certainly cannot afford to lose people of this calibre, nor can Australia or this parliament, because they have both contributed so much in their different ways. In 1998, the National Party took on One Nation in the political arena. We bore the brunt of their electoral onslaught. The results for the National Party could have been disastrous, but we took them on and fought them off. Those who might one day think that Australia does not need a rural based party should reflect on what would have happened if the National Party had not existed in 1998. We endured casualties, which we pay testament to tonight, but we won the war and will help the wounded to come back.

Sandy fits the traditional mould of a National Party parliamentarian: he is from the land, a wool grower and a grazier. He brought tremendous experience and expertise to this place. He was at the cutting edge of policy development on problems facing the wool industry and looked after their interests. Whether we froze the stockpile or changed the way that wool was sold or privatised it, Sandy was always there in that debate sharing his knowledge on the issues facing the wool industry, which is still the sixth biggest exporter in Australia and faces tremendous problems, as it has done over the last 10 years. So much of Australia can grow nothing but wool. Many country towns depend on it. It is very important to have a rural voice like Sandy's in the Senate and the parliament.

From a broader political perspective, Sandy won the last Senate place in New South Wales in 1993 and shifted the balance of power, enabling government to get many bills through with Independents' support. He cut his teeth on native title legislation. He had the courage to stand up for his constituents. In his first debate he crossed the floor with Bill and Julian. I remember a funny night when, during that debate, I had cause to upbraid Sandy for not staying in the chamber, because it was a crucial vote and we had to be there. His answer to me was that he was shocked and that `he hadn't been spoken to like that since he was a jackaroo.' But he never held it against me.

Native title continues to shadow Sandy's political life—still being debated till recently. It is an ironic twist that Sandy's Senate place will be taken by Democrat Aboriginal activist, Aden Ridgeway—and I wish him the best for when he comes in. One Nation cost the National Party seat in New South Wales. It cost rural people dearly, because they lost a voice and gained an eloquent advocate for native title in return—hardly what they wanted.

Sandy was head of the Taiwanese Friendship Association. With that, he got the beef tariffs down in Taiwan to the level of the American tariffs—and they had a favoured nation treatment. That was a wonderful gain for rural Australia but, again, Sandy never got the recognition he deserved.

He was chairman of the black spots committee, chairman of the Senate foreign affairs committee, a member of the joint committee on foreign affairs, and a member of the joint committee on ASIO. All these positions meant a sensible National Party voice in important policy considerations. In a recent Telstra debate, Sandy worked on the bush's concern over replacement of analog telephones. He made sure that the analog was not switched off till the CDMA was switched on.

At a personal level, we do not have cliques and rivalries here in parliament, although friendships are formed. But I have never heard Sandy say a bad word against anyone. I have never seen him not being able to approach anyone in this chamber. Sandy is an outstanding sportsman. He has a supportive family. He is barbecue cook extraordinaire for the Boswell Christmas bash. He is the epitome of a good parliamentarian—getting on with the job of doing day-to-day diligent work in the background, making this country a better place, especially for country Australia. Sandy's favourite verse is from Les Murray:
You ride on the world-horse once.
No matter how brave your seat
Or polished your boots,
It may gallop you into undreamed-of fields.
In the future, `the world-horse' is not finished with Sandy yet. There are many fields yet to gallop, and I firmly believe that at some time Sandy will be back in the Senate saddle.

By contrast, Bill breaks the mould of the National Party stereotype—not from the bush but with a legal financial background. Also with a young family, he is a keen sportsman and bobsled champion. But I know Bill as a fearless and eloquent speaker with a brilliant mind and a photographic memory whose talents are going to be sorely missed in the National Party and in this parliament.

Bill has been an outstanding party whip and has brought his clever mind into play in numerous exchanges in the chamber. He has been a courageous defender of rural Australia and an able defender of our constitutional system of government. He has no hesitation in standing up for his principles and has crossed the floor several times. He has been instrumental in treaty making reform—ensuring they cannot be made in secret but would be open for parliamentary scrutiny—and this will never be able to be wound back. He helped me in that CoT cases win—that David and Goliath battle with Telstra where senators joined together and came out for fairness and justice. He has been on the black spots committee.

But all this fades into insignificance, because Senator O'Chee's most outstanding contributions lie in his courageous stand against One Nation, including speeches in the Senate. Despite tremendous pressure, Bill refused to budge on the One Nation preference issue. In doing so, Bill saved the National Party from itself and ensured sufficient credibility for the party to retain other seats. It was a very painful episode for Bill.

The National Party has much to thank Bill for—not only for his advocacy in the Senate but because he refused to give in to the forces of populism, prejudice and negativity. They are not the way forward for our people. One Nation has cost rural Australia dearly—and nowhere more so than in the loss of these two senators from the National Party. As to Bill's future, the law of probability says that Bill will not get back in, with only a thin sliver of hope following the High Court's decision against the British One Nation candidate. But this man has nine lives—and I would not like to rule him out. For my money, I am backing him.

I would like to conclude by emphasising that the National Party of Australia is a very proud political party which consistently faces electoral threats to its survival. The party is not one person or one year or one event, but a force which relies on young, positive people like Bill and Sandy to stand up and be counted in public life.

talk.start.para: —I usually have no trouble speaking, but tonight I have butterflies in my stomach and sweaty palms. That is very unusual for me in this place. Senator Faulkner mentioned that they have discovered that I have a sense of humour. I did always have a sense of humour; it just was not very obvious.
—Not much to laugh about here.

—In this place. That is right. I have actually been walking around with a smile on my face a lot more often most recently, and I guess that is because there is a great deal of personal relief in the pressure that has lifted as a result of the end of my term—even though I did not choose the end of my term. I cannot deny the disappointment of losing the seat. I tried to find the extra 5,000 votes. I kept looking and looking, and my partner would let you know that in the middle of the night I thought, `They've got to be somewhere!' but they were not. There they were, hanging on the end of the third candidate for the Labor Party, but they just did not come across. However, there are a range of reasons.

speech.para: For me, the greatest sadness is losing that Green connection for Western Australia that started, of course, with Jo Valentine in 1984—for whom I handed out how to vote cards in the little town of Bridgetown. And that, of course, was followed on so ably by my colleague Senator Christabel Chamarette, who is warmly remembered by so many people in this chamber. So yes, there is grief; but it is tempered by personal relief. As I say, I will not deny that I tried to find an extra 2½ thousand votes—somewhere, anywhere—but it was not to be. From the Greens' point of view, we say that is the cosmos—because, if one door closes, another will open.

I tried to think about what I set out to do and whether I have achieved it. Essentially, no, because what I wanted to be was redundant. I wanted to be in a party/movement that became so obvious to people in terms of its approach that it became the mainstream and commonsense. Some things that we have done have done that, but I just wish I was redundant. Unfortunately, we are still going to need Green politicians for long time yet.

There is, of course, no end—to the Green politician—of political representation. I refer, of course, to my colleague Senator Bob Brown and his team. The Greens all work with teams: Marg, Ben, Geoff, Jo, Steven and all the people who contribute to your office. I want to say how much I have admired your contribution. For those people who always like to pick out differences, can I tell you that the Greens value and celebrate diversity. There is always more than one way to represent a green electorate.

I remember back to Jo Valentine, who was never, and was never likely to be, in the position of holding the balance of power. But she was the most-known senator in Australia. I believe that polls showed that people knew of her and the work she did. That is because she was visible, as is Bob Brown.

talk.start.para: —She certainly was: she was in the slammer.
—She had courage, yes. And I tell you what: it takes a lot of courage to stand up in that way. It is not easy. I have immense admiration for what Jo has achieved.

speech.para: I have said that I have not achieved what I set out to do. I looked back at my first speech and the issues which I put on the record. It was, I think, one of the parliament's shortest first speeches, being about 7½ minutes. I was in a hurry and I wanted to get going.

I talked about globalisation. I talked about my desire to have people understand some of the issues. I would like to think that, over time, some of the things I have said have actually made it into mainstream debate because they have been mentioned at the political level, but I cannot say that I have succeeded in that area.

I also talked about the fact that, at the time, I wanted to see that the issues of ecological sustainability could be seen as interacting with the economy. I have worked so hard to integrate those issues. I have always recognised that it is not in the areas of environment and social issues legislation that we get the major changes and policy changes; that generally it is in issues of trade, economic policy and sometimes corporate policy that we actually get most of the changes involved with the environment, social policy and social justice. `It is about the economy, Stupid,' I guess is the kind of response that we see happening when we want to actually change things and get people working in a different direction.

How did people greet us when we got here, certainly when we found that the numbers were such that we shared the balance of power? I guess derision was probably one of the first things I would say. The term `fruit loops' did pop up, and the `Gumnut Twins'. We appropriated that—yea! Even the friendly commentators, who thought they were being chummy, wrote stories of the `Pooh Bear goes to Canberra' variety—assuming two things. One was that we would simply follow a major party and vote always with that major party—because, of course, being little Greens and women, we would not know any different. And don't you all wish we did! However, the other assumption was that, if we did not do that—

talk.start.para: —You haven't voted with us yet.

—That is true. The other was that, if we did not do that, we would simply fall on our face, because hey: how would we understand those big issues to do with money and the economy? Well, we did not do either. There are stages, as former Senator Chamarette used to say, of cognitive dissonance. Basically, first you are ignored and nobody knows you are there. Secondly, there is derision. Thirdly, there is anger, once they work out that they cannot shift you that easily. Finally, if what you are saying reaches enough people, then those ideas become mainstream: you find them three years later actually in government policy or in legislation.

speech.para: At no stage, unfortunately, do we ever get the credit for those ideas, if they were originally on the cutting edge of the political debate. Of course, in many instances, if they are outside the general debate of the major parties, they do not get coverage at all, because they are not recognised as issues of importance, even if they are representative of issues involving many people.

I want to move on quickly because I want my staff to have a direct say in this debate. I want to thank the little voices in the community who every now and then, and not infrequently, reminded us of what we were here for—yes, community participation and decision making is very important to us. Just moving back to the Fruit Loop packet; we did keep the Fruit Loop packet which someone very kindly sent us in our office window for a time until we finally binned them because I did not actually like the taste of them. I have kept the Fruit Loop earrings. I have kept that symbolism because they represent to me the connection between growth in world trade and environmental damage.

I confess embarrassment at my own election slogan, which relates to `hardest working', because I know in reality that it means, technically, I just spoke more often than everybody else. In fact, and it is like the duck going along on the river, the people working with me were certainly some of the hardest-working people I have seen. Anything I have achieved is because of the people around me, the team and the network. The whole has always been much greater than the parts.

I would now like to use the words of my own staff. When I asked my staff to give their contribution here they reminded me that it is what Christabel did as well. So if you will bear with me. Carole Perry, my wonderful office manager from Perth, whom many people have spoken to over the phone, said:
As I close the doors to Dee's office for the very last time on the evening of 30 June 1999 my heart will be heavy with sadness.
For six years I have waited for this House to produce a vision. Alas, I have waited in vain.
Acid rains, global warming, ozone depletion and inappropriate farming and mining practices are clearly showing us the catastrophe threatening life on earth.
To quote the European Greens, "only a new solidarity can save this planet for future generations".
Species are vanishing a thousand times faster than the natural extinction rate.
Industrialised agriculture and aquaculture and forestry based on the destruction of our ancient trees are destroying our planet forever.

I am sad because the people of Australia recognise these problems. We want to stop this dangerous trend. We want our children and our children's children to inherit the Earth we were privileged to know so long ago.
But I am also angry, very angry, that you—the Members of this House, who represent the people of Australia—will not listen to us.
Instead, you make the laws easier so that we can be locked up or heavily fined when we protest about the need for justice and the need to save what remains of this beautiful country.
You pass legislation that is responsible for the poor to become poorer. You allow health facilities, education and employment to be almost beyond our reach.
And you smother our voices and our avenues of protest.
Please reconsider your actions and think again.
Stuart Reid, our most recent electorate officer and very hard worker, says:

With only a minute I'll leave out silverchair's Anthem for the 21st Century and instead reflect on two popular culture references from my generation which vividly contrast alternate visions of our possible futures.
On the one hand—from Led Zeppelin—a vision of a future in which people and communities take control of their lives and participate fully in the political life of their society:
It's whispered that soon
If we all call the tune,
Then the piper will lead us to reason.
And a new day will dawn
For those who stand long
And the forests will echo with laughter.

And on the other hand—from King Crimson—a future in which more and more people are disenfranchised and alienated from the political process, where the distance between the haves and have nots becomes ever more stark:
Blood racked barbed wire
Politicians' funeral pyre
Innocents raped with napalm fire
Twenty first century schizoid man
Death seeds blind mans' greed
Poets' starving children bleed
Nothing he's got, he really needs
Twenty first century schizoid man
I am very much afraid that the latter is where we are headed. . . , but, in the long run, there is still time to change the road you're on.

Many people will know Amanda Bohnen and the work she has done for us in managing our office and her quiet professionalism—and I am very proud of the confidence that she has shown in the work which she has done. Amanda says:
If there's one thing I've learned whilst working for Dee it is this:
If Australians knew the tireless, devoted hours Senators put into their work, they would be much slower to criticise.
If Australians appreciated the ever-increasing complexity of a Senator's workload, they would be far less demanding.

And if Australians recognised that Senators are not despots, but people entrusted with a special responsibility that they're trying devotedly, for the most part, to fulfil, they might show greater understanding.

An ounce of patience and encouragement and forgiveness can and does go a long way in this political hothouse. I've seen it, on brief occasions, do remarkable things and I want to thank all those people who have shown these qualities towards Dee.
I would like to think that Australians will rise to the occasion and show a bit more of these qualities to those who come to follow. In the long run it will be for the benefit of us all.

Many people will know the wonderful work that Liz Peak has done as my economics adviser. Liz started as a parliamentary intern and I spent years working out a spot where Liz could join us as a permanent staff member and she has been fantastic. Liz says:

Initially, I wanted to leave a message for parliamentarians—a message to listen to the community, and care what they think, and imagine what the impacts of decisions might be, and realise how privileged you are to be here.
I also wanted to leave a message of idealism that expressed my passion for equity, justice, the environment and community participation.

But as I am lucky enough to be able to express these idealisms every day in my job—I want to say how thankful I am to be able to be involved in politics and not walking away totally despondent and disillusioned.

Despite passage of many horrific bills and cynical deals, I have been lucky enough to work with so many people of utmost integrity and principle—everyone in our office and all the wonderful and energetic and inspiring greens, activists, and community groups. These people have left me with a strong hope that in the future we will see principles and people prevailing over politics and profits. Our groovy poster in the office says it all: the future is green!!!

Far from least, I thank Alan Carter, who I think everybody in Parliament House knows. I think most people recognise what a fantastic personal assistant he has been for the work that we have had to do. (Extension of time granted) This is a poem by Adele Coombs:
How tempting it is
to want a piece of this country—
to `own' some of its space,
make our dreams come true,
build our heart's desire,
be it haven or empire,
and call it `our place'.
But the land never belongs to us.
It's only lent with awesome freedom
to create and replenish,
or waste and strip bare.
What legacy will we leave
alongside our footprints?
What will be left to share?
Though it endures title-deed holders
the land is never ours to keep.
Long after the proud `owners' have gone,
merely campers moving on,
will the land still be here
to sustain our children?
Or will its fragile beauty be gone?

Mr Acting Deputy President, I also must give special recognition to my partner, Nic, who has always been there at the end of the phone and at the end of a long parliamentary session. I certainly do not know whether I would have been able to do what I did without him.

I also want to thank the many, many volunteers—and those others who have been with us on the journey. They include Anne, Shane, Andrew, Ben, Heather, Michelle, our legal adviser Gary Corr and many others. I also want to give special recognition to Kirsten, Dhanu and Matt. Few people will forget the work that Matt did through native title. Few people will forget Dhanu's colourful, ardent personality, and few people will forget the work that Kirsten has done here in this parliament and with Amnesty International. Where to from here? Well, certainly not to a television career. I have decided that is not for me after my Good News Week performance, but I guess I am surprised that after six years of our hard work in so many areas the media should have taken such an interest in my bodily functions.

Before I finish though, I would like to mention my friend Margaret Reynolds. I do not often say that about other party members because I realise that often a Greens parliamentarian calling someone a friend is a kiss of death politically. But, in this case, Margaret is safe. You're getting a life too, and I wish you the very best. We worked on uranium issues, on the uranium committee, on Aboriginal issues, on environmental issues, on nuclear issues and on women's issues, and I echo all those wonderful statements that people have made about you.

I wish all other departing senators well and hope that the time after the Senate is a new life, a new beginning. I would also like to say how thrilled I am that one of the new senators coming into this place is Aden Ridgway, and that we will have again an Aboriginal voice in the Senate. I think that is just fantastic.

Finally, I would like to thank the staff, the clerks, the research staff, the parliamentary house staff, the committee staff and all those people who we have worked with and who make this place work. I think we should value the independence, the professionalism and the work that these people do, and guard it and defend it for all its worth. Democracy and justice is worth defending.

talk.start.para: —Wasn't that typical! It is a real pleasure to listen to Senator Margetts. I say that because when she gets up to speak people listen to her, not only in the committee stage but on occasions like this. I would like to say that it was typical. She was not claiming credit for herself but recognising teamwork. It was so pleasing to see her recognise her staff and particularly Alan, whom we all know. We often tend to take for granted the work that our staff do. On this particular occasion, let me first of all wish you all the very best, Senator Margetts.

speech.para: I would like to also acknowledge the work that has been done by the staff of all of the departing senators. The departure of their senator from this place is difficult for them. They too will have to enter into new work, new places and a new environment, and that is not easy. I think we all acknowledge the wonderful job that our staff do and also, as Senator Margetts said, the work that is done by the staff of the Senate, the staff of the Parliamentary Library, the staff of the Joint House Department, and so on, to help democracy to run in Australia. All the very best, Dee, and we enjoyed that speech.

I am not going to be long. There are 22 speakers to go, and if each of us takes 10 minutes we will be here until 2.30 a.m. I will be brief. I believe brevity would be the best possible gift I could give to the departing senators because we want to hear from them rather than their hearing from us, but I must refer to all the departing senators.

Senator Colston was elected in the same election that I was—he in Queensland for the Labor Party in 1975 and I in Tasmania as an Independent. Senator Colston has been under a considerable amount of pressure over the last few years—personal, public and health wise. His family has also suffered. I do not think we should forget that members of parliament feel a great deal of concern for those whom they love, particularly their own families. In a way, it is unfair for those families to be visited with the type of criticism that is often levelled at politicians.

We sometimes forget what people have contributed to this parliament. For example, Mal Colston has contributed vastly to this Senate. He has worked consistently on committees. He was a very good Chairman. You knew, when Mal baulked, you could not go any further. You could try him out when he was in the chair but you knew when he baulked that he would not cop any further nonsense, and that made this chamber a more manageable place. I think the work that Senator Colston has done for this parliament and for this Senate should be acknowledged here. I wish Senator Colston and his family well in the future.
Senator MacGibbon has been around the place for a fair while, too. I think it was—what 1978 or something?

talk.start.para: —It was 1977 that he was elected. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate has said, he has been very interested in and done a lot for defence in this country. Earlier on, I can recall him being rather dismissive of my efforts, at least, and I suppose others, of getting more money for development assistance for developing countries. His view—as was expressed, I think, in 1981—was, `Why shouldn't it come to Queensland?' But over the years, his work in the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was very well recognised. He became chair of the Defence Subcommittee, but he also contributed substantially to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which of course examined issues of development assistance, and he, of course, obviously, over the years, participated in this work. I wish David very well in the future, and I am sorry to see him go.

speech.para: Senator Margaret Reynolds, I wish you, too, all the very best. I must say that our joint interests and concern for Aboriginal people and also the work that Henry has done has meant that I have got to know you much better over the years. We do wish you very well, and I hope you do see a bit more of Tasmania in your retirement.

Senator O'Chee, I wish you and your family all the best. When he came here he was single. He was supposed to be working very hard as a senator, but obviously he had time to catch—and I must say, she is a marvellous catch, your wife—

talk.start.para: —He went fishing.

—Yes, he went fishing. He and his wife now have a lovely child. I wish you all the best, too, Bill. It has been indicated that Bill is a vigorous debater. There is no doubt about that. He would have to be, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate said, one of the best, if not the best. I think he said that he is the best debater in this chamber. Your debating skills were evident, but your contributions in this chamber always had quality and substance. You will be missed.

speech.para: Senator Sandy Macdonald, your family plays a big role in your life, as it should do for us all. I might just say that it was great to see the O'Chee and Macdonald babies here around the place. People like yourselves should get a medal from the Treasurer, be cause we do need more taxpayers coming along, and we should not forget it! Senator Macdonald, the bush will be back here. I am sure, from the messages that I am getting around the place, that we will see Senator Macdonald back. Anyhow, I wish you all the best, Senator Macdonald.

Last, but not least, Senator Synon. She has been here only a very short time, but I have been impressed with Senator Synon's work, particularly in the committees on which we serve. I am sorry to see her go because I am sure that she would have contributed significantly and uniquely to the work of this parliament. I know I am getting on, but it is always interesting to see young people—young members and senators—come into this place, and I think that she had a lot to contribute. Maybe she will be back again. In the meantime, I wish you all the very best.

talk.start.para: —I too would like to pay tribute tonight to the colleagues who are leaving us. Senator Harradine said that we must make it short. In my contribution tonight I would just like to highlight one thing which will remind me of those people who are leaving us, something that I think would remind me from time to time of the mark, the little bit that each one who performs in this place leaves upon you. I am sure, as you work through this, that there are particular things you remember and particular marks that are left behind.

speech.para: First of all, I want to start with Mal Colston. If I think of one thing when it comes to Mal Colston, it is courage under fire. I really mean that. Mal Colston has been here since 1975; he was preselected during that time at least four times, if not more. He had some great difficulties, but I think the way that he stood up to the pressure that was applied is something that should leave a mark on each one of us.

What does Margaret Reynolds remind me of? In particular, her interest in Aboriginal affairs, which is something that is also very close to my heart, and those who have heard me speak in here would understand why. What I admire most about Margaret in terms of Aboriginal affairs was not that we did not always agree but that she was always keen to find or look at another solution to the particular problems that exist with our indigenous people. Those of us who have spent much of our lives out in the country recognise and know that there are number of concerns.
And then there is Dee Margetts. What does she remind me of? It is her passion for her cause, a quality that is often lacking in this place.

When I think of David MacGibbon I think of air, air and air; I think of air controllers, air controllers and more air controllers; I think of the Air Force, the Air Force and the Air Force. I cannot think, having heard what Senator Faulkner said tonight, of a better person to become the Chairman of CASA and take over from where Dick Smith left off.
Senator McKiernan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You would all be safe, I promise you. Dick Smith retired.

speech.para: Karen Synon, I was fortunate enough to know you before you came into this place, even though that was for a short time. Your time here has certainly been too short, as has been said. The thing I remember most about Karen is her maiden speech. I remember it well, before I came into this place, I spoke to two people with regard to what you should do when giving a maiden speech. One happened to be Fred Chaney and the other one was Wilson Tuckey. They both said to me at that time that you should make sure that your maiden speech spells out who you are and what you stand for. It is absolutely crucial not only because it gives a message to everyone and the people out there who elected you but also because it is something you can go back and read from time to time; you can measure yourself against that maiden speech. I think in the short time, Karen, that you have been here, you have certainly stood firm in terms of the principles you laid down that day. I think that is incredibly admirable and, hopefully, it will also be the beginning of your coming back.

There are many things you can think about Bill O'Chee. Debating skills have been mentioned and his research capacity at estimates. But, Bill, the one thing that I remember very much, which not many people here saw, was when we were at Wellington. You, Senator Cooney and I were the Australian delegates to the Commonwealth conference on legislation scrutiny. For those of us who heard Bill's contribution to that conference, it was simply outstanding. It really spelt out the importance of personal liberties and the rights of the individual. I think that was one of your great contributions, which not many Australians heard. I was fortunate.

Finally, I come to the person I did the most work with amongst the people who are leaving here tonight, and that is Sandy Macdonald. Sandy, I just want to say thank you, particularly for the last 18 months. When the industry which you and I both grew up in—and there ain't many of us left here, mate, not many of us at all; I am talking about the wool industry—needed a sound mind, a person to stand firm and to bring our committee back to order, you always produced those words of wisdom and that calming effect. What I will remember you for, Sandy, is that particular contribution. What you did for wool growers was to create hope in a wool industry that had had 10 years of hell, absolute hell. For those people who are in that industry, that contribution—the solidness of it, the sincerity of it and the wisdom of it—is worth recording here. Even though it went through difficult times, is going through difficult times, it is still ranked sixth in importance in our export industries in this nation. It is still the greatest multiplier in terms of employment of any industry in this nation. I predict this industry will start climbing back up the ranks through these records, as it rebuilds under the new arrangements that have been put in place. While I am taking a bit longer on you, I think your contribution has been very important. On behalf of myself and for the support you gave me and also, I would say, on behalf of wool growers in this country, thank you.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief. As the whip, I have been in a privileged position to actually be able to comment on all of those senators who are retiring because I have probably seen a side of them that other senators might not have seen. To Dee Margetts, I have always found her to be very sincere and dedicated and I would like to thank her for the cooperation she has given to me in whips meetings. I wish her well with her masters degree, and I certainly wish her well if and when she goes back to Christmas Island.

speech.para: As has been said before, Dave MacGibbon has been around for quite some time. I always respected his advice. I do not think anybody knows the standing orders better than Dave MacGibbon. He is the only senator who comes and asks for leave personally, which I find rather quaint, and he has never abused leave at all.

talk.start.para: —He does not leave your office until you give it to him!
—That is right. He is a very persistent person who appreciates it when he does get leave. I wish him well on his cattle property.

speech.para: Margaret Reynolds is a Tasmanian born senator whom I have shared temporary chairman duties with. I recall very well when she was minister for local government because I was chairman of the local government committee and spent a lot of time shadowing her. I wish her well in retirement.

I recall also being a temporary chairman when Mal Colston was chairman of committees. Mal used to have meetings of a morning that included breakfast, and I always found that very enjoyable. He used to lecture us consistently and persistently about our duties as temporary chairmen. Those of us who have been temporary chairmen for a long time will remember the advice that Mal gave to us. I wish him and his family well.

Bill O'Chee has been the National Party Whip, and of course we have worked very closely together. It has been a pleasure to work with Bill. I guess there are a few times when Bill has turned up on time. Most of the time he is late, but I must admit that when Bill is on duty I reciprocate. Sometimes when Bill has to make a point to me I get it in writing and I return the favour in writing. Bill, your future is in banking and finance, and with Tara and Rory you have got a great future. I do not know whether you want to come back to this place, but wherever you go I know you are going to be successful. I agree with everything that has been said about you, particularly by Brian Harradine. Mate, I wish you all the best. I would like to thank you very much for allowing me the good fortune to obtain a wonderful whip's clerk, who, as you all realise, has had to put up with a fair bit of pressure since Claire went on holiday. You trained Suzanne very well. I am still learning from her some of the other ways of doing business.

As has been said, Karen Synon has been here for a brief time. Karen, can I say that you have been a great team player. You have done everything I have asked of you and more. I know that sometimes you have had to fill in on committees that you did not want to. You have had long weeks of committee work but, whenever I have asked you to substitute for another person and help me out, you have been an absolutely great team player. I wish you every success in future, whatever you choose to do.

For Sandy Macdonald, I guess it is back to the farm with Alice and the twins, but I do not think you will be there that long. You have been a very distinguished chairman of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. I would like to commend you on the wonderful work you have done as chairman of the Taiwan Friendship Group. No-one has worked harder than you and no-one has achieved more than you have. I think you have done a lot for Australia-Taiwan relations, and I will always remember you for that, amongst other things.
I guess that is it. To all of you who are retiring, bon voyage, and we hope to see you back here at the old boy functions from time to time.

talk.start.para: —I will resist making any comment about old boys' clubs.
—Unusually restrained, Rosemary.

—I think that is not quite fair. I am usually restrained. If you only knew the full truth of my thoughts. Tonight I simply want to take the opportunity to join in support of everything that Senator Faulkner had to say on behalf of the Labor Party this evening and say some words about a particular friend and colleague in Margaret Reynolds. She came into the Senate in 1983, at the same time as I did, so we have travelled a fair distance fairly closely together. Margaret is a person about whom I can only speak with the greatest admiration and affection. Perhaps it goes to the point just made, I hope with some kindness, by Senator Patterson, but there is a difference between Margaret Reynolds and me. Margaret is unfailingly kind, charming and civil, and you can entertain what small differences from those characteristics might fit me.

speech.para: In particular, what I like so much about Margaret Reynolds is that, despite the provocation—and there is plenty in this place from time to time—her qualities that I think of are her gentleness and her constant civility. If there is a gentle way of finding a solution or working through a problem, Margaret is the person who will seek that and find it in every situation. I have never seen her driven to fury or extreme but I have seen her cope endlessly with all sorts of things that might have led her to react that way. I thank her very much for modelling, under the constant pressure of politics, that it is possible to be forever the same decent person that you are out of this place and out of parliament.

Margaret has established and persisted with a constant agenda about the issues that I think go to the heart of the Labor Party: questions of social justice and in particular her commitment to human rights in all shades and varieties of how human rights can be proposed. Her work on behalf of Aboriginal people and with Aboriginal people has been exemplary and I think an example that many others of us have been pleased to take a lead from.

She has also been tireless in her campaign for and on behalf of women. We were recalling earlier this week that when we first came into this place we were told that the Senate Hansard was a record of everything that was said in the parliament. Margaret and I were two of the people who chronically noticed that despite the fact that we used expressions like `he and she'—being describers of the world in non-sexist language—Hansard regularly reduced that to the third person masculine. I learnt this very quickly because I picked up one habit from Gough Whitlam and that was to read the daily Hansard every day. I could not believe that all these words under my name were really there. I still get a thrill seeing the words I have said written in Hansard. But it was very frustrating to read things that I did not think I had said. Sometimes I even referred to notes to check what I had said and I knew I had not said that. I had said `he and she' so why did it say `he' only?

In the end we rose and asked Mr President if he would take note of this. Hansard claimed to be a record of what was said, but indeed it was not. It was an editorial practice as well. I believe that Margaret and I, and I would put in there Pat Giles and Olive Zakharov, to say nothing of Susan Ryan—the women in the Labor caucus—were very concerned to see that Mr President was able to institute changes so that Hansard changed a practice which they assured us was as old as the parliament. Subsequently what was said in parliament was recorded in Hansard and women got yet another forum where they were truly recorded as having said certain things and those certain things were written down forever. I was interested in the effort it took to change just a simple practice like that. It was one of those many things that Margaret and I stood together on.

Another thing about Margaret is that she has the very rare skill of being able to turn a political idea or policy into action. There are any number of times when I can only say I learnt again and again from Margaret: what an interesting way of developing that further—whether it was a letter to be signed, a petition, the wearing of peace badges or any number of things all the way through to a sorry book. Margaret would say that it was not entirely and utterly her idea, but certainly it came into this place as something we could act on and not just talk about. So I thank you for that, Margaret. I do not have the skills so I may have to call you often.

One other thing I want to say about Margaret is that she is a person who has established and maintained an extraordinary network of parliamentary, political and community colleagues. People maintain that contact with Margaret and are pleased for her to contact and maintain the contact with them because of the genuine way in which she listens to what they propose and say and the way in which she has acted for and on behalf of all those people. I am still aware of knowing the extreme range of her contacts. Very few people achieve anything like that same network of people who are prepared to ring and propose an idea, ask for help or seek further information. I note these are not the headline issues in Margaret's political contribution. They go much more to her role as minister and parliamentary secretary, but I remember those things as consistent throughout all her political contribution.

I am certainly going to miss you, Margaret, very much. The Labor caucus will miss you—a conscience if ever there was one. It is not just in parliament that Margaret had the capacity to draw matters to the attention of all those assembled. She was the conscience quite often within the caucus too, and being the conscience in our caucus is not the easiest road. I might say that you are not the only conscience, but certainly on a number of occasions you have been. I would also say that Margaret has a rare capacity to enlist people to her conscience's cause and very often she was successful in the issues she raised or the points she wanted caucus to attend to. We will miss you. We will miss you for your warmth and for your friendship and for your unfailing contribution and encouragement to all of us to keep on keeping on.

I heard Senator Margetts—I think at this stage we are probably being unparliamentary and referring to people by their first names, so it is Dee tonight if I may—say earlier that one of the goals she hoped for was that she would become redundant, that the issues she wanted to raise were no longer issues. I am pretty sure you can rest easy—you will be wanted for a long time, Dee. I certainly want to say exactly the same about Margaret Reynolds. The issues that you have raised are not finished with. We are not sure and secure that the things we achieved in the past will remain. Certainly we promoted change and we hoped that that would be an improvement, but many of us can say that it will be a matter of great regret that the constant way in which you, Margaret, have kept those issues alive and provoked us to come at them again and to persist when lots of other people are inclined to tire or flag are all of the things that I would want to put on the record as marking your characteristics in particular in this place.

There are many things I would love to say to Margaret, but they would be much better said outside this place. You would not want them all on the record. None of them are nasty, I assure you. They are more in the nature of: let's have a drink sometime and talk about them. I think Margaret knows full well some of the things I am talking about. I want to take this opportunity to thank Margaret for her contribution not just to this parliament but to me and my participation in this parliament. I wish you well. I wish Henry and your children well and I hope you enjoy very much your new life wherever it takes you.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the remarks of my leader tonight in this valedictory session. I wish to speak briefly and pay tribute to two women who will be leaving. Before I do, I would like to acknowledge the contributions and the commitments of the other five senators who will be leaving and to put on record, on behalf of the Democrats, that we wish good health and good luck to Senator Colston. As to Senators Synon and MacGibbon, for the record it would be appropriate for us as Democrats to congratulate and commend them on their particular interests in human rights: in the case of Senator Synon, her involvement in the Amnesty organisation and her line on Burma and Tibet, which we also share; and in the case of Senator MacGibbon, as has been mentioned tonight on a number of occasions, his particular involvement in Bougainville.

speech.para: As to Senator Sandy Macdonald, I remember my former boss, Senator Karen Sowada, when she lost to him, saying to me, `If I had to lose to anyone, I am kind of glad it was Senator Sandy Macdonald, because he is such a gentleman.' I think that is probably a view that all Democrats, and certainly I, would share. Not that we were glad to lose Karen—quite the opposite—but indeed he has always been charming and very gentlemanly. As to the other Nat, Senator Bill O'Chee, before he just exited the chamber he came over and said, `Kid, I'll be listening from Senator Macdonald's office,' and I thought I was not going to put on record the fact that for the past almost four years he has called me `Kid'. For someone who got in so young—and I am talking about Senator O'Chee—he has consistently called me by that name.

I have respected Senator O'Chee's intelligence and debating skills. Obviously, we have very different politics but in my early days he provided me with sometimes not needed but nevertheless useful procedural advice as well as—I think and I hope—a friendship. We have often been dragged out by various publications, as the youngest ever male and female senators, to talk about our politics and our perspectives and, as I say, they are probably not particularly similar. But to Bill: you have my respect and my best wishes.
To Senator Margaret Reynolds, to whom I particular want to pay tribute tonight: when she first got in I note she said:
I speak to this chamber as a member of the Labor Party, a woman, and as a senator for Queensland. These three loyalties shape my experience and determine my priorities as a member of this chamber.

Indeed they have: she has served with great compassion and dignity. Her work in the areas of feminism, women's rights, indigenous rights and population issues is acknowledged by all and will be long celebrated by many men and women, but in particular by women, in this place and I think by many women yet to come. You have given me great faith in sisterhood, Senator Reynolds, because you do support other women, and for that I congratulate you.

Lastly, I refer to a woman who also does believe in sisterhood. When I first got into this chamber, Senator Dee Margetts and Senator Christabel Chamarette actually moved a notice of motion to support me on my election. At the time I thought that was a rare display of cross-party support, but it is something, Senator Margetts, you have shown time and time again that you are more than capable of. You have my enduring respect and admiration. Your commitment to social justice, feminism, the environment and indigenous issues is ongoing, and I strongly support that. As for a sense of humour, no-one who saw your recent television performance could deny that. What a high point that was—and that is no pun intended, Senator Margetts. Senator Abetz obviously knows what I am talking about. In your first speech, you certainly acknowledged that you celebrate difference and diversity and you said, `The difference between Senator Chamarette and me is that Senator Chamarette is nicer.' I do not necessarily believe that. I think you are equally nice, shall we say, or do—as Kaz Cooke would say—keep yourself nice. In addition to that I would certainly say: keep strong, keep passionate and keep feisty. That is something that many of us respect in you and admire about you, and I wish you all the best for the future and look forward to contact with you in the future.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support all our colleagues in the Senate in this valedictory to senators who are retiring on 30 June. While it is inevitable with the passage of time that all of us will leave this place, there is no escaping of course a feeling of sadness in saying farewell to friends and colleagues. From a Queensland perspective, we have four senators leaving and they are Senators MacGibbon, O'Chee, Colston and Reynolds. I want particularly to refer to my fellow Queensland Liberal senator, David MacGibbon. I first met David when he was a senator-elect in 1978. At that time I personally did not have any inkling that I would be joining him some 6½ years later. In those days there were only two of us from Queensland and David showed me the courtesy of introducing me to the ropes both in Queensland and in Old Parliament House about the same time, Mr Acting Deputy President McKiernan, as you joined.

speech.para: I must say that it was a very tough time for the Liberal Party in those days, probably the toughest time in its whole history, and I know he, understandably, is gratified with the significant role he played as we increased the Liberal Senate representation in Queensland from two to four. Much has been said of David's parliamentary career, of which of course he can be very justifiably proud. To me the things that stand out have been his intellect, his firm support of the parliamentary system and—as Senator Hill pointed out—his regard for the importance and the dignity of the Senate.

From a personal perspective, I would like to pay tribute to his steady resolve, dedication and labours to make Australia a better and safer place, not only for this generation but also for future generations. This is borne out by his consuming interest over the years in foreign affairs, defence, trade and national security. His interest in defence was first evidenced in his being a national service recruit, where he saw benefits both for individual character building and the Australian community at large. In the early eighties he took a strong stand, making speeches on the difficult decision to spend $2,000 million on either the F18 or F16 fighters. His penchant for defence arose from his own personal fascination with aircraft. Flying had been a strong hobby interest for David long before he entered the Senate and his love of aviation has, over the years, led him to be regarded at various times as a civilian expert on fighter planes.

As an aviation enthusiast, his interest in flying spilled over into his day-to-day life so much so that, by the late 1970s, David found that his pastime of collecting plane parts had overflowed the capacity to house them in his home. It became apparent that there was not enough bedroom space for his children. Rather than jettison his collection, he resolved to build a new house and designed it around the novel idea of an aircraft hangar.

There have been many issues that David MacGibbon has championed. He pushed for the sale of TAA, the deregulation of the airline system and the privatisation of Qantas. He took up issues on the Australian flag and SBS. He pushed for equal employment opportunity legislation. Other matters related to coastal surveillance, air safety standards and customs. Yet other areas of interest have included the charity sector, the Senate quota system, child-care accessibility, human rights, small business in Queensland, and rural matters such as drought relief and market prices to name only a few of the matters that he has taken up over the years.

However, it would certainly be true to say that David MacGibbon's priority has been matters relating to Australia's defence capabilities, with an emphasis on ensuring professional standards and financial accountability. While tackling these issues, he has also shown interest in the treatment of ADF and ASIO personnel, especially with regard to safety matters and obtaining recognition for the work of our security forces—people who often put their lives at risk in the course of their duties.

David's wife Pam and his four children have been very supportive over the years of a job that, as we all know, often takes us from our homes and families for long periods of time. On behalf of the Queensland Liberal Party and on behalf of Queenslanders, we thank you for your enormous contribution over 20 years and we wish you success in whatever you do in the future. One thing I do know for sure is that you will do it with great determination, dedication and integrity.

I would now like to turn to Senator Bill O'Chee. As a fellow Queenslander, I have known Bill well since he entered the Senate nine years ago as a Queensland National to occupy the seat vacated by John Stone. I think Bill still holds the record as the youngest senator to enter this place. He was young in years but very mature. Someone made the point earlier—I think it was Senator Hill—that he has matured even more. I think the great surprise for Bill was when he got preselection. He was a dark horse—a young, little dark horse. He is also the first person of Chinese descent to sit in this place, and that is a major mark for Bill.

Despite his youth, Bill O'Chee came into the Senate well qualified as a legislator, with a degree in jurisprudence from Oxford and world-class debating skills. Following Oxford, Bill had a short stint as a capital markets broker in Brisbane and London. He has distinguished himself in the Senate with his intellect and with his ability to quickly get across and to speak on a wide range of legislation.

He did not confine himself to youth issues but pursued a variety of rural, regional and small business matters—in fact, just about any topic. I can remember in my days in the ministry when we would get those inevitable take note of answers after question time. If you wanted to get a quick response from somebody, you would give about three notes to Bill O'Chee. He only had to talk for five minutes but I know he could have talked for 20 if he wanted to on an issue that one would think he would not know a lot about. He did it with great conviction, I can tell you.

Bill O'Chee has made a very valuable contribution with his work on many committees: legal and constitutional; foreign affairs, defence and trade; and rural and regional affairs. As everyone has mentioned, he was the National Party Whip for six years. Even in his final months, Bill has worked hard as a member of the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System, which had an exhaustive workload as it travelled around the country.

Bill is well known for the strong links that he forged with Chinese and Taiwanese communities in Queensland and for his strong, principled stand against racism, which perhaps came at electoral cost to him. It is a great detriment to the Senate that Bill leaves this place prematurely. However, it is the right age for him to make the transition to a business or corporate career. His intelligence, integrity and capacity for hard work will stand him in good stead in his next career, and I am sure he will make a great success of it. I am equally sure that his family will welcome him being home more often.

On behalf of the Queensland Liberal Party, I would like to thank Bill for all the work he has done in this place and, by extension, for our state of Queensland. I wish you all the best in the next stage of your life, Bill, as well as great happiness for you and your family, Tara and Rory—and maybe many others. I will be awfully surprised if we do not see you back here again.

I turn to Senator Colston. I guess there are probably few people in this Senate who have experienced such a roller-coaster ride in politics as Senator Colston. He was nominated by the Labor Party to replace a deceased senator in the 1970s. The incumbent government of Queensland at the time appointed somebody else. He was subsequently elected in 1975. In 1990 the Senate went against past practice, and he was elected Deputy President when the Liberal nominee was rejected. In 1996 he abandoned the Labor Party and was again elected Deputy President. In this instance the Labor nominee was rejected. So he saw both actions. Subsequently he relinquished that position.

I served on two committees with Senator Colston. As Senator Boswell said in his speech, `I always take people as I find them.' Senator Colston was chair of both of those committees. They were the good old days when the incumbent government chaired all of the committees—I just make that comment. In both instances, Mal Colston carried out his duties with great decorum and dignity. He has, in more recent times, been diagnosed with a very serious illness. His wife has also had treatment for a very serious illness. All I can say to Mal Colston, his wife Dawn and his very supportive sons is all the best for the future.

I will just touch on the others who are leaving, because I know we have been told to speed up the process. They are in no particular order. Sandy Macdonald has been a great friend. He has made a major contribution while he has been here in what has been too short a time. He is a victim of an attack on the National Party, as was Bill O'Chee, which seems to be an anomaly in Australian politics; which I hope it proves to be in the future. It is a tragedy that you have been forced out under those circumstances, Sandy, but I believe you have an awful lot to contribute. This experience will stand you in good stead and I am sure you will be back like General MacArthur.

Karen Synon has unfortunately had a brief time in the Senate. As Paul Calvert said, Karen has been a great colleague and a team player. The thing I like about Karen is that she and I agree on just about everything.

talk.start.para: —She must be very sensitive.
—She is mature beyond her years. No doubt Karen, with her commitment to the political arena, will have a future career in politics, and I wish her well.

speech.para: When I first came to the Senate, I thought Margaret Reynolds was an old hand—she certainly gave that impression. Then I discovered she had come here only a year earlier. She has done a great job over the years for her party. She has diligently pursued a number of causes. I heard the remarks by Senator Crowley about your gentle, kindly nature, Senator Reynolds, and I could not help but agree entirely with them, although your commitment we all knew about. If you could excuse a male chauvinist expression to an old feminist, I think you are a real lady.

Finally, Senator Margetts and I have had a couple of fiery encounters over the period, but at no stage did I ever doubt the fact that she was entirely genuine and consistent in the views she put. You cannot say much more than that. I believe that she was probably misguided, and she knows she will excuse me if I say that. Still, she was very genuine and very committed, and I do not think you can say much more about a person.
To all our colleagues who are leaving, I say collectively all the best for the future in whatever career you decide to follow.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this occasion of a number of senators retiring. I do so because one of them is my colleague Senator Reynolds. I will make some remarks about her in a moment.

speech.para: To Senator MacGibbon: I have served on the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee for nine of the 12 years I have been in this place, and during all of that time David MacGibbon has been a member of that committee. During the three years that I was chairman of that committee, David was a very effective member, particularly on the defence subcommittee. I think it is a fitting tribute from his party and from the parliament that in the last period before he leaves us he has been chairman of that committee. It is true that David was one of the few members of the parliament who had a genuine interest in defence. Even though estimates committees and the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee can often be a forum for debate from different party political positions, David was always extremely genuine, in opposition or in government, about getting the best for the defence forces of Australia.

His technical knowledge was second to none on the committee and even though one may disagree with some of the views he put, I thoroughly respected his view and always listened carefully when I was chairman and when I was a member of the defence subcommittee with him. David's work on the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee of this parliament is one reason why it is the pre-eminent parliamentary joint committee in the Australian parliament. I wish David well in the future. I do not think he will retire; I think he is far too active for that. I think he will go on with those issues—many of them have been mentioned here by other senators—with considerable success.

Senator Margetts has had six years in this place and this brings to an end 14 years of representation by the Greens (WA). When Jo Valentine was elected in 1984, I thought it was a flash in the pan from Western Australia. The Greens proved me wrong by maintaining their representation—in many senses against all the odds—until the last election; until next Wednesday. You would all agree that Senator Margetts was extremely consistent in the position she put, even when she was in a very small minority. Reg Withers once said in this place, when he had to change a position dramatically because of a change of policy, that consistency in politics is the sign of a small mind. In that case, you might say that Dee Margetts has a very small mind because she has been extremely consistent in the views that she has put on behalf of the Greens and on broader environmental issues. For that I compliment her, even though I sometimes strongly disagreed.

I also point out that she has been a very effective member of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee and showed a particular interest in defence, being on that subcommittee and attending estimates when she was a member of the committee. Recently she asked a series of questions for over an hour about the submarine contract. Her knowledge of the technology of it showed that she was aware of the very complex issues in considerable detail. Dee Margetts has been a very effective senator for her cause, and I pay tribute to her. In many ways—I say this with some affection—Dee Margetts might well be called an old style Trotskyite because of the fact that she was always on the side of those who wanted to change institutions and radically reform a range of issues in society. In many of those areas, I think she has every right to be proud of her achievements.

There are a number of other senators leaving, including Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator O'Chee from the National Party. I have not served on committees with them. Senator Sandy Macdonald's office is down the corridor from my office and after a division we often have a chat. I agree that Sandy is a real gentleman and a very pleasant person to deal with. When we are able to chat openly at a private level and discuss things without any sense of political partisanship, it makes this place work better.

For Bill O'Chee, it is ironic that somebody with a Chinese background has been a victim of the One Nation campaign—that dreadful campaign leading up to the last election. I pay tribute to Bill. He fought the case against them very strongly in Queensland when it might have been much easier to duck the issue. In the hotbed of the lead-up to the last federal election, and in the Queensland state election, although Bill made a couple of predictions that did not turn out correctly, at least he stood up and fought against One Nation when it might have been easier to duck and slip through on the issue. For that, Bill should be very strongly commended.

Senator Synon has only been here a short time and I have not served on a committee with her. I understand that she is a dedicated political activist within the Victorian Liberal Party, so whether or not she comes back here, I suspect that she will be in another part of Victorian Liberal Party politics for quite some time.

Finally, I want to turn to my colleague Senator Reynolds. In 1983, at the time of the calling of the double dissolution, I was a member of the national executive of the Labor Party. That was the first time that the national executive intervened and did the Senate preselection at a double dissolution for all states and territories. The national executive had just won a court case to say that they had the power to do that, so they exercised it to get all the tickets done and out of the way to stop brawls in various states. I was sitting there next to John Button and when we got to the Queensland ticket he said, `Listen Schachty, with Jim O'Keefe just retiring—the senator based in Townsville and the former President of the Labor Party—we have to have a senator from North Queensland. Margaret Reynolds' name has been put forward. She has been on the council and very active up there. You have got to vote for her.'

I admit that I did not know Margaret from a bar of soap, but on John's say-so I voted for her. Margaret, I have to say that I have never regretted in any way making that decision because you have been an outstanding senator, not only for North Queensland and Queensland but also in this place for the Labor Party and all the people of Australia. People have mentioned your interest in human rights issues and support of the underprivileged and women's rights, et cetera. It is a list far too long for me to mention in the short time that I have, but I would say that there is one contribution that you and your husband, Henry, have made to the Australian community. Between you, you have brought to the fore issues that this community had had amnesia about—that is, the way this country had previously treated Aboriginal people.

Many of us, 20 years ago, were completely unaware of what had happened in this country both in the last century and the early part of this century—everything from the stolen children to the wars, and they were wars, where Aboriginal people were massacred. Most of us had not been told about it; we were unaware of it. I think you and Henry have played a seminal role in opening up those issues and making them major moral and ethical issues for all the Australian community. What is so satisfying, and must be for both of you, is that it is now a major issue at the forefront of debate and discussion in the Australian community.

Whatever other achievements you have had in this place, you will be remembered for leading the way for that issue to be brought forward, as it has to be if we are to have any sense of a nation with a moral foundation. We cannot be that without the recognition of what happened to the Aboriginal people over the last 200 years. I am sure that there are many indigenous people who will thank you more profoundly than I can express here, but as a person whom you and your husband awoke to the issues, I thank you very much for that. I know in the years ahead you and Henry together will continue that great work and it will not be a retirement; it will be a continuing good job that you will do. Thank you for being an effective member of the Senate. You have made a difference.

talk.start.para: —I asked a good friend of mine tonight, Hal Colebatch, what you say to retiring senators. He said that, `Well, I suppose you could say, "Now they belong to the ages".' He was referring to the quote used in relation to Abraham Lincoln when he died. I think that is a bit dramatic, but nonetheless it has some application. Tonight, we are looking at some people who have served this Senate and this country—people who have come from all different walks of live and who are not going to leave the cloisters of the Senate without continuing to serve their country.

speech.para: I turn first to Senator David MacGibbon, who has had a long and distinguished career in the Senate. When I was a new senator, I was lucky to have his advice in relation to an Senate inquiry in which I was then engaged and which touched on defence. It was then that I realised the depth of his knowledge in relation to defence and his corporate memory in relation to events in the Senate. I came to discover that more so in relation to matters concerning the party room and various issues which arose from time to time. I say to David and his wife, Pamela, that I wish you the best. David has made a fantastic contribution in the Senate and one which perhaps goes back to a day when the Senate was a different place from today.

More recently, when I arrived in this place in 1993 with Sandy Macdonald, things indeed changed. It was then that I met Senator O'Chee. Both senators were from the National Party: one from New South Wales and the other from Queensland.

I will firstly refer to Senator O'Chee, whom I served with on the legal and constitutional committee. He is a senator whose knowledge of procedure in this chamber is second to none and he will be sorely missed by the government. I say to you, Bill, that you have served the Senate with distinction. You realise the importance of this institution. I recently found that Senator O'Chee, as the chairman of the Regulation and Ordinances Committee, was not adverse to even saying to the government when he thought a regulation transgressed certain rules, precedents and conventions. He made his views very well known. You might say that he gave the minister a hot news flash and I can tell the Senate that that minister was me. Bill, the only thing that I can say that I am glad I did resist was your invitation to go for an early morning row on Lake Burley Griffin and I am glad that I resisted that to this day. To you, Tara and your delightful son, Rory, I wish you all the best and I hope we see you back here again.

In relation to Senator Macdonald, I was lucky to serve with Sandy on the print media inquiry, which was a rather torrid inquiry. In fact, I vividly recall Cheryl Kernot saying in the heat of the moment to Kim Carr, `I wouldn't leave you alone in a room with a quorum.' I often reflect on that. But it was a situation where there was a diversity of views, to say the least. I am always minded in relation to Senator Macdonald to think of that part of Kipling's If: `If you can keep your head while all those around you are losing theirs . . . ` Certainly, Sandy Macdonald is a man who keeps his. I think the word `gentleman' has been used tonight and that is an apt description in relation to Sandy Macdonald. To Sandy, Alice, Millie, and the twins, William and Angus, I say, `All the best for the future.' Sandy, your children will look back and be proud of your contribution. However, I think his contribution is not yet finished. I think there is still another chapter to be served, which may well be in this chamber.

I also would like to make reference to Senator Synon. Karen Synon has only been here a brief time unfortunately. She has been a great supporter of voluntary student unionism, a matter which has been a burning beacon to the government and to those on this side of politics, which really centres on voluntary association—a matter which goes back in excess of 20 years. Karen, you have reinvigorated this debate. When some of us were tiring and perhaps lagging behind, you gave us that energy and refreshed the debate.
