I thank you for that and wish you and Joe all the best in the future. Again, you are still of that age when we could well see you again in this chamber.

My comments are brief, due to the hour. We also are farewelling Senator Reynolds, whom I served with on the native title committee. The word `civility' is one which has been used tonight and it is one which I wish to endorse. Senator Reynolds and I, I dare say, would have very different views on many matters, but that is something that does not seem to get in the way of service on the Senate committees.

I think that really we could all descend into some sort of cynicism in looking at politics and on these sorts of occasions when we have these valedictories. But as an old barrister in whose words I used to place a lot of store used to say, `It is not so much what is said but that it is said.' I think it is time for the Senate to take stock of contributions made by various senators. Senator Reynolds, you have represented your side of politics well, your point of view well, but you have done it with decency and civility, and for that I commend you.

Senator Margetts also has views I would not readily associate myself with, but then again she has represented a sector of Australia and has put forward her views vigorously at times. I think it is a tribute to Senator Margetts that her staff were here tonight in the chamber to see her valedictory. I think it is a great tribute to someone when their staff have that loyalty to them. I also liked the quote from Led Zeppelin, an old favourite of mine.

talk.start.para: —You old rocker.
—Senator Abetz said that Senator Margetts is an old rocker. I do not think she is as much of an old rocker as I am.

speech.para: For those who are listening I think it needs to be said that you have senators here who have come from all walks of life, senators who have served their country well and have served the Senate well. The Senate is a very fine institution and it is one of which this nation can be proud. I say to those who are leaving, `You have done well by your country, and I do not think you will let it stop there.'

talk.start.para: —Valedictories are a funny and peculiar time in this chamber. We have heard a National Party senator being called a gentleman and nobody took a point of order! It got even worse when we heard Senator Reynolds being called a lady and that person escaped without water or something worse being tossed on him! It is a unique experience to speak in valedictories. It does bring it home to all of us, I believe, because we have all in turn, who have spoken so far, reflected on our own passage in this place and our own experience with the individuals who are moving on to another sphere in their lives. We are in turn paying tribute to them and recalling the good times that we have shared with them in the brief passage of time that we have had in this chamber.

speech.para: I am going to be mercifully brief tonight. Apart from a passing reference to Senator O'Chee, I am only going to speak about two male senators and two female senators, so I am balancing things. My passing comment about Senator O'Chee picks up remarks made earlier tonight by my leader, Senator Faulkner. With Senator O'Chee's political demise it probably will come to me now to have the worst male dress sense in the chamber. That is something that perhaps Jackie will have to draw further attention to.

I want to particularly say goodbye and farewell to Senator Richard MacGibbon—or is it Senator Robert MacGibbon? The funny thing about Senator MacGibbon is that he could never remember my first name, and it is the easiest part of my name. He keeps remembering me as Michael so, when Senator Crane tonight suggested that Senator MacGibbon ought to be put in charge of Airservices Australia, I actually freaked at that. If he has got no memory for as short a name as Jim, that would cause me some problems. But I do understand that he has got some real expertise in that area. It is an expertise that I recall from my early days in this place: when I needed some information on one of the very first estimates committees that I served upon, he was quite willing to share with a member of the then government while he served in opposition, and I wish him well on that.

With Senator Sandy Macdonald I have had the privilege of serving on very demanding committees: the Senate Publications Committee and the joint committee on publications. The most demanding thing about that committee is the time that it meets in the morning. Perhaps my greatest failure in this place is in trying to get the time shifted to a more reasonable time—like it used to be when I chaired the respective committees. I probably hold the record for the shortest committee meetings of two to three minutes, and we did not need to meet in the middle of the night in order to get the business done. The meetings still start at a quarter past eight in the morn ing, and I will try to be there next week to attend his last meeting.

Senator Calvert, the current chair of the Taiwan Friendship Group, referred to Sandy's great work in that organisation. That work is recognised by this parliament but also by our friends from Taiwan, and they took the opportunity in recent months to pay tribute to and to thank Sandy for his good work. That is something that is recognised as above and beyond the call of duty in this place.

Senator Margetts, all of us Western Australians wonder about our eastern states colleagues and give sympathy to them when they complain about having to travel that vast distance across the continent to Perth for committee meetings or whatever, and then sympathise even worse when they have got to travel home. We know what they go through, because we do it day in, day out. Senator Margetts does it as well but she does not have the support of the party system, which I have from the Labor side of things, and which Senator Campbell has from his side and which Senator Ellison, who has just spoken, has. Senator Margetts still serves her state as a single member senator and she also travels extensively within the state. Even though we do not share the same political viewpoint on all things, we certainly have a number of things in common, and that has already been referred to.

Senator Margetts has an enormous amount of energy. She mentioned in her contribution tonight about her workload. I think she was measuring her workload by the number of times she has spoken in the Senate. I am not so sure that is such a good measurement of workload. I remember, as you will, Mr Acting Deputy President, another individual senator, who has passed on now, who probably put more words into Hansard than any of the current senators or any other senator.

There is a habit—I think it is an ever increasing habit—of getting up and reading things into the Hansard without necessarily understanding what is being read. One of things I am amazed by, and I stand in awe of Senator Margetts, is her contribution on so many subjects, matters that are of importance to her and her party and the people she represents in this chamber. There is also the fact that she seems to understand what she is talking about. She is not just blandly getting up and reading material that somebody has put down for her to read. I think that is a tribute to Dee Margetts and a tribute that might not have been given to the same degree to her predecessors in this place, and even to some of the current senators who serve the parliament in this place.

Finally, I want a say a few brief words about Senator Reynolds—or should we say `Lady Reynolds', when we can get away with it? I notice she has got a glass of water and that the wine carafe she has with her is still empty. She squibbed out on a dare and a challenge I made to her earlier tonight. Of all of the people I have spoken about tonight and paid tribute to, Margaret Reynolds would be the one person with whom I have argued most, and I do not argue very often with people in the chamber. The reason we do is that we are in the same party. We get to meet each other more often than not and, not only that, we are in the same faction. That gives us cause to create that dynamic that is the Labor Party—the Labor Party that was in government and is now in opposition, and the Labor Party that is full of ideas and is willing within itself to talk things through and forcefully press the point.

The things I have not argued with Margaret about are issues dealing with Aboriginal affairs, native title and land rights because I am not in the same league as Margaret Reynolds on that subject matter. I accept, and have always accepted, that Margaret knows and understands a lot more about that subject than do I as a migrant to this country. I echo all of the words that my leader, Senator Faulkner, said about Margaret earlier this evening, and I join with Senator Schacht and Senator Crowley in the words they put on the record about you and, indeed, about your husband, Henry. I take this opportunity now to wish both of you well in your new life. I do not think it is going to be a retirement, but I certainly wish you and the rest of your family all the very best in your new life.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to say a few words about those of my colleagues whom I know reasonably well and who are leaving us next week. There is always some sadness when colleagues leave and I guess there is some sadness for them, but also there is some happiness for them knowing they will be able to go back and lead some sort of a normal life after this place. When I first came in here I was put onto a committee inquiry into private hospitals and nursing homes. Pat Giles chaired that committee and Senators Walters, Crowley, Bjelke-Petersen, Janine Haines and Margaret Reynolds were also on it. Senator Reynolds was a lady even then—although I am told you cannot call women `ladies' any more, you have to call them `women'. You are a very nice person, and I do not think I ever heard you use the language that was used by some of the others on that committee at some of the hearings we had. It was a pretty daunting task, I can assure you, being with a group of women on a committee at that stage.

speech.para: I also served on a committee with Senator Colston. He has been here since 1975. During that time, he has performed an amazing amount of committee service. When I was on that committee, the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, as the deputy chair, he was the chairman. He was an outstanding chairman, and I believe he was also an outstanding Temporary Chairman of Committees, as a couple of people have already said here tonight. I hope that Senator Colston enjoys better health in his retirement than he has had in this place in the last few years.

I also mention Senator Synon. I really did not get to know her. She has been here for only a brief time. I must say I have to give Dee Margetts a little bit of thanks for making some of the legislation that I had to put through this place non-contentious. She was able to be negotiated with, even though I do not think I ever saw completely eye to eye with her, but she had her principles and she stuck to them. David MacGibbon served this place well. Anyone would have been proud to have been a senator over the period he was here.

I am particularly sad to see two of my National Party colleagues leaving the Senate, and Senator Tambling will join me in the remarks that I will be making. Bill O'Chee and Sandy Macdonald will be missed not only by the National Party but by all their colleagues in the Senate. I will not elaborate on the words that have been said about them before here tonight, but I concur with all those remarks that have been made. They have both played a significant role.

Senator O'Chee came here in 1990. He was a young gun—he still is a young gun actually. His youth and enthusiasm were really quite infectious to all of us. He has done an excellent job as a whip. Bill, you have always kept us in place, and I think you have done an excellent job there. You have always been a great contributor to debate, and I think everyone has said that tonight. It is not easy coming to the Senate and getting up and speaking without any notes, without a prepared speech, which you often have to do. That is a gift that not many people have.

You have been incisive in your debate and you will be sorely missed by everyone in this place, not only for your debating skills but for your analytical appraisal of issues within a debate. At least you understand what a lot of the bills are all about. A lot of people in this place probably do not understand them as well as you. Let us not forget your profile as a bobsledder. You are going to be sorely missed in the car park where you did your training for some of the events that you have been so successful in overseas.

I most admire you, Bill—and this has been said by everyone here tonight—for the way you stood up and confronted One Nation. You never backed away from your beliefs, even though it would cost you votes—and it did. You stood firm, and I admire you for your strength of action. I am sure that you will make your mark in the business sector before you return to this place, if you choose to do so. I am quite sure that this parliament and the government would welcome you back. You are an outstanding parliamentarian cut short by a group of people in Queensland who did not really know what they were doing when they voted.

My colleague Senator Macdonald from my home state will also be missed. Sandy was elected to this place in 1993 and, in his short term here, he has made a significant contribution. He has been active in the wool debate. Of course he always said that there was no conflict of interest in any of that, but I know he runs very good sheep at Wallabadah and good cattle too, just quietly. He will be sadly missed by this place as well. I admire Sandy for the way he acted in the wool debate—he made sure that the wool industry was handed back to the people who actually produced the wool to let the people at the grassroots make the decisions.

You have been active in the debate on communications affecting the bush; rural doctors was a matter that you took a very strong stand on; and you played an active role in the debates on the sale of Telstra and native title, but I did not cross the floor with you—neither did Bos, by the way. In recent years, you have been very active in foreign affairs issues and recently participated as an observer in the Indonesian elections. I still have not had the full report from your visit there to the election, and I hope that we get that before you leave the Senate.

There need to be more voices representing the bush in the Senate, and it is sad to see one of the loudest, Sandy Macdonald, leaving. However, both of my National Party colleagues have young families, and out of something sad something good always comes. I am quite sure that the silver lining will be that you will be able to spend more time with your young families and enjoy that experience. Might I say, being a father and also a grandfather of, at this stage, eight children, they grow up all too quickly. You are on this earth only once, and therefore you should savour every opportunity to be with your children.

When Bill O'Chee came into this place, he was unmarried with no children. He leaves with a lovely wife, Tara, and a son, Rory. When Sandy came in he was married to Alice. He is still married to her, which is great because she is a most wonderful woman. He came in with no children. Their first child, Millie, came along and now they have William and Angus. Not everyone who comes into this parliament has the opportunity to have twins—obviously Sandy has had a bit of time at home, because I did not see Alice down here in Canberra that often. Unfortunately, this place does not allow us enough time with our families. I think we are away too much. You should both savour the time you have before you come back to this place in the future. I wish you both well in your future careers, and I know you will achieve in whatever profession you choose. I wish all retiring senators all the very best in their retirement from this place.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I join with my colleagues in wishing all the retiring senators well, including Senators Karen Synon, Sandy Macdonald and Dee Margetts and, in particular, my four fellow Queenslanders, Bill O'Chee, Mal Colston, Margaret Reynolds and David MacGibbon. I heard earlier the comment about Senator Reynolds having come from Tasmania and trying to understand North Queenslanders. As a North Queenslander I think it is appropriate to say that there are five states in Queensland: Far North Queensland, North Queensland, Central Queensland, South-East Queensland and Western Queensland. They are states of mind, and until people south of the border—whom we call Mexicans—have experienced them, they will not understand us Queenslanders.

speech.para: This, the occasion of valedictories, is, I believe, the only time that we should ever be here after the witching hour. I sympathise with the clerks and the attendants, but this is a great opportunity that has been given us. I am here particularly out of a sense of gratitude to David MacGibbon. David is not speaking tonight. That is characteristic of him; in fact, it is typical of him. He is a modest man who has never courted personal publicity or media attention. I believe that he has been underappreciated by the wider community, but he has been appreciated by his friends and in particular by his family.

Many do not know that he has quite an outstanding family. He has four children: Dr Jane MacGibbon is an astrophysicist, research scientist, and a graduate and gold medal winner from the University of Queensland who attended Cambridge and worked for some years with NASA; Dr Anne MacGibbon is an obstetrician and gynaecologist; Ian MacGibbon is a graduate in agricultural science and is a regional bank manager and grazier; and Douglas MacGibbon is a mining engineer who works with BHP and is also a grazier. There is also, and above all, his wonderful wife Pam, who is also a grazier. They have been immensely supportive of David over the years that he has been here. He and John Watson have been here since 1977 and, apart from Brian Harradine and the departing Senator Mal Colston, they are the longest serving senators here.
We are all honoured to serve in the Senate for without the Senate there would be no Australian nation.

The Senate has been a particular interest of David's, I know. He has served it well, and others have spoken of his appointments to various committees of the Senate and his particular interest in science, the environment, foreign affairs and defence, rural and regional affairs, and economics. In his maiden speech he referred to his interest in science. His occupation before he came here was prosthodontist—many people would have to look up the dictionary to see what that is: it is the reconstruction and replacement of missing teeth. After the State of Origin the other night, I would think that would be more appropriate for the New South Wales and Queensland Rugby League teams.

David forswore that when he came in here at the age of 44, and he has made a major contribution. As a matter of fact, he is a workaholic. He has taken few holidays. I looked up his CV and saw that he has taken only five trips with parliamentary committees in the 22 years he has been here. Nonetheless, one of his recreations is flying. I think Warwick Parer referred to the fact that he built a room onto his house. I was with him when he was constructing a plane in the room of this house, which he actually got out of the house and flew. It is still flying, I believe, although I have never had the privilege, nor did I actually want it, to go with him at any stage.

He believes passionately in the Senate. He has played a major role in bringing about the peace accord in Bougainville. He has been a product of the organisation in Queensland. I know that he has been a member of the party for 33 years. He will return to the organisation, because he has a passionate belief in what the Liberal Party stands for, and I believe that he has a further contribution to make in that regard. I cannot finish without also referring to his staff, who are almost part of this family, particularly Carmel Draper, who has been a wonderful support to him in all the time he has been in the Senate, and Sally Kay. David will make good use of the time that he has outside the Senate. As I say, he is a workaholic. He will make further contributions to the party and to his state of Queensland. I think that his time is not finished in relation to politics because of his belief in what he has done and what he is doing. I pay tribute to him for that, and I look forward to his further friendship.

talk.start.para: —Tonight we farewell seven senators—my best wishes go to all of them. To Senator Colston, with his health difficulties and uncertain future, I trust that he will find satisfaction in the considerable public service he has given to our nation. His knowledge of standing orders is superb. In his role as Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee he showed me, shortly after my arrival here, the finest traditions of the Senate, especially in its review role.

speech.para: I have a small anecdote: some two years ago I had my lovely daughter with me in Canberra. That particular week she was supposed to be seeking sponsors for `Jump Rope for Heart'. I promised to take her around the corridors to seek sponsorship. Armed with a skipping rope and a sponsor card, we hit the corridors. Most senators were generous with a gold coin. Senator Colston, on being convinced that my daughter, Laura, could skip, handed me a gold coin, albeit in somewhat of an embarrassed state. I did not understand why. Later that day, Senator Colston emerged at my office with a more substantial contribution, explaining his embarrassment at the small contribution he had made earlier that day and indicating that it had been the only money left on him at the time. That anecdote and his consideration, I think, speak volumes and show a side of his personality that is not necessarily appreciated. I wish all the best to Senator Colston, his wife, Dawn, children and, above all, his grandchildren and the grandchild that I know he is hoping to be able to see.

Senator Reynolds, although a feminist, will, I trust, accept my clumsy attempt at a compliment by saying that she is a true lady. Working with her on ERCA and the native title committee, I witnessed a genuine senator at work. Whilst I try desperately to understand some of her views, I am convinced she only ever wanted one thing, and that was the betterment of our country. Any past sins are atoned for by her impending move to Tasmania, albeit I understand the northern spirit is still deeply embedded within her from North Queensland and, as a result, I believe she has chosen Launceston. But welcome on board.

The other senators that I will refer to do not leave of their own free will. Senator Margetts is hard working, committed and has subjected herself to the hard work of detail. For that she deserves acknowledgment. Although hardly ever agreeing with her world view, I do recognise her passion and commitment.

To my coalition colleagues: Senator MacGibbon's talents as a professional legislator, his corporate knowledge and his intricate knowledge of defence matters will be missed. I note and also welcome the fact that he will continue to serve the Australian people on the Defence Industry Advisory Council. His knowledge and expertise, therefore, will not be lost to the Australian people.

To my country cousins Senators Macdonald and O'Chee, I unashamedly say: I will miss you. Your friendship, your sense of humour and assistance has meant a lot to me. When I first started off in this place I was on the very outskirts of the Liberal Senate seats and sat next to the National Party senators. I especially appreciated the times during question time when we enjoyed sharing interjections, potential interjections and baiting of the Democrats, a sport which is now frowned upon by the government. I will say no further on that.

To Senator Macdonald—a true gentleman, he is a loss to the people of New South Wales and I trust that he will soon return. He is far too young to retire with such a wealth of talent to offer. His commitment to serving his nation still burns within him. I trust that flame is not snuffed out and that he will soon return.

Now to Senator O'Chee, a great bloke with a wicked sense of humour that I appreciated, a capacity to give a bit of curry to our opponents and a clarity of thought unparalleled in this place. Above all, I admire Senator O'Chee's courage. The most courageous thing I can think of Senator O'Chee ever doing is having the cheek to ask Tara to marry him. How he did it and how she in fact agreed I will never understand, but well done. As with his choice of marriage partner, Bill always pursued excellence. His capacities will ensure his success to whatever he turns his hand. To Senator O'Chee, Tara and Rory, all the best.

I seek to pay special tribute to Senator Synon. I have known Senator Synon for over 20 years. Her capacities, loyalty, teamwork and drive are unsurpassed. Her background of working for a decade with young unemployed people in the western suburbs of Melbourne provided an expertise rare in my party. On her arrival in the Senate, she was the youngest ever Victorian Liberal senator. Her arrival also gave the Victorian Liberal division the distinction of being the first major party to have a majority of female senators. She also provided, if I might say, much needed generational change. As of 30 June 1999 all that will be lost to the people of Victoria.

Senator Synon is a compassionate conservative. Her first speech was mailed out by me to a number of people in Tasmania because of its intellectual rigour, its clarity and the message of challenge to our people. It is now on the public record that Senator Synon's term was cut short because of pre-selection skulduggery. Having had my advice sought on certain pre-selection irregularities, I came to the conclusion that she was dudded. I later instructed Tom Hughes QC who confirmed my preliminary views and indicated a watertight case if court proceedings were to have been taken. But Senator Synon put her party first; she put party before self. For someone as passionate about politics as Senator Synon, that was a very big ask.

Premier Kennett's breaching of the Victorian Liberal constitution to effect this outrageous outcome was something that the organisational wing should have had the strength and integrity to expose and reject. It not having been so rejected, he is now wreaking similar havoc in state preselections. Preselections ought to be jealously guarded by the organisation against blatant interference by the parliamentary leader. Enough said on that. Suffice it to say that I trust that the Victorian organisation will reward Senator Synon's loyalty and correct the gross injustice perpetrated on her by a rigged preselection panel.

Senator Synon has a supportive husband, Joe, a person also known to me for over 20 years. His support to Senator Synon during the disappointment of the preselection loss was, I know, a great strength to her. Senator Synon's passion and support for freedom of association for students in Australia is shared by me and is much appreciated by Australia's 600,000 students. I say to her, through you, Mr Deputy President: the fight for voluntary student unionism will be won. The `no ticket, no education' regime that currently exists is draconian and will be abolished. The right to an education should not be predicated on membership of a student union. Senator Synon, you have fought for that principle. You have breathed new life into that campaign and that will be a great monument to your very brief period in this place. Senator Synon's contribution, short though it has been, has been significant, considered, dignified and an example to us all. I hope to see Senator Synon back in service to this great nation.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I wish all of the retiring senators all the very best in the future. Because of the time constraints, I want to confine my principal remarks to two of the senators with whom I have had the most dealings—Senator Margaret Reynolds and Senator David MacGibbon. But briefly may I particularly wish Senator Synon all the very best. In the short time I have known her, she has shown a very great determination for the causes in which she believes. I am quite confident that we will see Senator Synon back around the political traps some time in her future.

speech.para: Senator Bill O'Chee entered the Senate a fraction before I did. He is a fraction younger than I am as well. At times we have shared part-time offices in the Cairns region. Again, I am sure Bill has a very good future in whatever he determines to do. I particularly want to mention and recognise, as others have done, the courage he showed in the fight against racism and against One Nation.

Senator Sandy Macdonald will also, I believe, be back in this place in the not too distant future, so I will not say too much. His departure at this time will mean that I get my mail slightly quicker, rather than having it apparently go through Sandy's office most of the time. I will also appreciate getting my wife back, as very often Sandy is invited to functions with Lesley Macdonald, whereas I have the pleasure of being invited with Alice. I look forward to being invited with Alice again at some time in the future.

Mal Colston—doctor, major, senator—is a very colourful political character. He has already written one book, prophetically entitled The Odd One Out, and I look forward very eagerly to the next book that Senator Colston will write. Senator Colston was Deputy President between 1990 and 1993 when I first came here as a very junior senator. I particularly remember Mal Colston's kindness at a time when I had my wife and some friends here. At that time nobody could come into this chamber but senators, and that was very carefully guarded. But Mal, in his impish way, saw us looking through the door and, as Deputy President, invited us in—at a time when the Senate was not sitting, of course. I have never forgotten that kindness and neither have my wife or our friends.

Dee Margetts and I have never had much in common at all, but I do acknowledge her dedication to the causes in which she believed. I have a very special regard for Senator Margaret Reynolds. Again, Margaret and I do not share a lot in common in the policy area, but of course we do both share Townsville and we both share an interest in local government, both of us entering local government in our respective councils in the Townsville region in the same year of 1979. Margaret has been—and she will hate me saying this, as others have said, but I have to say it—a gentle woman in all senses of the word. At times Margaret has had the opportunity to score cheap political points at my expense, but she has resisted that, and I do appreciate that from her. Margaret's commitment to policy issues, involving particularly women and Aborigines, is legend. She will be missed in the Townsville political scene, and I do thank her very much for her courtesy and cooperation over the years.

David MacGibbon, in structure, in principles, in commitment, in knowledge, in recognition, in ability, is a very tall man. But, particularly for me, I respect and have been a beneficiary of his leadership in the Liberal Party in Queensland. He is one of those real Liberals of honest Liberal philosophy and action. He lived through the fairly tumultuous days when the Liberal Party in Queensland was at its lowest ebb, but he never faltered in his commitment to the Liberal Party. That, of course, makes the manner of his departure a little more difficult to understand. His wide range of interests stem from his background as a specialist dental practitioner; an academic in universities in London, Michigan and Queensland; a pilot; a national serviceman; and, with his wife and family, a Central Queensland grazier.

I often recall—and I know Ron and his team will forgive me for saying this—that in those days when we Liberals in Queensland were not quite as close to the National Party as we now are, and we are very close now, David MacGibbon would loudly proclaim that it was only the Liberals who were genuinely interested in rural Australia. And, even more loudly, he would claim that of all Queensland senators he was the only one with a genuine rural connection. I think it is of some satisfaction to David that the significant advances made by the Liberal Party in Queensland have occurred in recent years when he has been a leading member of the party in Queensland.

David's expertise in defence matters is widely acknowledged, and he was by all recognised for his work as Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on ASIO and on the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. David must leave here well satisfied with his contribution to the direction in which Australia is now heading. It is almost unnerving to see how David in his maiden speech pre-empted success of governments in their reform of tariffs and protection. The goals that he championed in his maiden speech for lower taxation and for more emphasis on the family are ironically being delivered in the last weeks of his term as a senator for Queensland in the parliament of Australia. My wife Lesley joins me in wishing David and Pam MacGibbon all the very best for the future, a future which I am sure will be fulfilling and rewarding.

talk.start.para: —I rise to thank my colleagues Senator O'Chee and Senator Macdonald for their service to the National Party, to their respective states and to this parliament. Having sat through my own valedictory in 1990, I realise that these moments for the departing senators are very emotive and reflective. Sometimes you might be silently saying to yourself, `Did I do enough over the time of my service?' Having worked with my colleagues in the parliament, the party room and the electorate, I can say that they can rest assured that they have met the requirements of their oath of office, which is their first and primary responsibility when they come into this parliament.

speech.para: In fact, Sandy Macdonald proved his mettle and genuineness towards his office within an hour of delivering his own first speech. I will quote from that first speech. Sandy Macdonald was talking about the wool growers of his electorate, in which he is well known. Sandy said:

Once out, the expertise is lost forever and all woolgrowers know the skills that are necessary to produce their product. Who will buy the land anyway if farmers are forced off? The banks must recognise this and I beg for their understanding.

When Sandy returned to his office for drinks with his family and friends following this speech, a New South Wales farmer, having heard Sandy's first speech, faxed a message to him alerting Sandy to his imminent bankruptcy—not Sandy's; the farmer's. The new senator, Sandy Macdonald, with a great deal of zest, immediately contacted the head of the National Bank, Don Argus, and within 24 hours he achieved a stay of proceedings and a review of that particular farmer's case.

This incident epitomised his style in politics. Within an hour of his first speech, he was true to his word. He is very personable and up-front, but I am not sure that he is a gentleman, as has been said frequently by previous speakers. Within four months of coming into this parliament, Sandy had the courage of his convictions—even though he was a new senator—to reject coalition policy and cross the floor on the native title bill on the issue of pastoral leases, a matter that was to dog this parliament right up until 1998 when we successfully passed the Native Title Amendment Act.

If the judgment of those three wise senators—Senators O'Chee, Macdonald and McGauran—had been followed at the time back in 1993 we probably would not have been so dogged. However, that is history and it is far too complex to delve into on this occasion. Certainly, it was an exciting political moment for Senator O'Chee, Senator Macdonald and me.

I know I could delve into Senator Macdonald's parliamentary debates, particularly on wool as others have, and on the issue of the stockpile touched on by Senator Crane, but something equally encompassing for this Australian rural man was that, when he visited South Africa, in Pretoria he came across the grave of Breaker Morant which was untidy and broken up. Like a true blue Australian he set out to fix this Australian shrine.

On his return to Australia he naturally contacted the RSL and Bruce Ruxton seeking support, if not funds. I am told that Bruce bellowed down the phone to him that Breaker was no better than Ned Kelly, a rogue himself, and he would not do anything to help him. Sandy was not deterred at all. Thankfully, we have a National Party Minister for Veterans' Affairs so Senator Macdonald approached Bruce Scott and today that site has been completely tidied up and it is a respected place to visit. That is Sandy and the Australian man—the Australian rural man; the words seem to go together—that he epitomises.

As for my other departing colleague, Senator O'Chee, he would remember that I gave my own valedictory in 1990. He was coming in and I was going out. As everyone has said, Senator O'Chee entered parliament as the youngest senator, and I would think that that record will never be broken. It is just unimaginable that we would get another Senator O'Chee type in here at the age of 24.

talk.start.para: —Not two of them!

—No. His stunning achievement has been that from that very raw base—if you think of any of us at 24 being thrown into this place—he has involved himself in so much throughout his nine-year career. His mental and physical intensity never faltered from the day he came here. During the nine years that he has served, his energy was a stimulus to a sometimes sleepy hollow party on issues no less important to the National Party than native title and Telstra, and all matters relating to immigration and racial tolerance. I would have to say that the exuberance he showed in those nine years often flowed over into his dress style. One celebrated occasion was his appearance on A Current Affair , when Ray Martin interviewed him. Suffice to say that his shirt, his tie and his waistcoat did not coordinate and were very fluorescent. Even I received mail about Bill O'Chee's dress; not that I could do anything. It was a stunning occasion. He warned us in his maiden speech, when he said, `I would hope that at no time here my dress offends.' Bill, offend, no; amaze, yes.

speech.para: I suppose there would be no senator who came through this place who did not think that their particular period was the most important in the nation's history, but there was something special about the period of service by Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator O'Chee. I am sure they would admit that, after 13 years in opposition, getting into government is an exhilarating experience, as is getting down to the hard work, which has produced historic results. They both played an important part in the backroom debates, not just in the National Party but in the joint party room too. As even Labor Party colleagues would admit from their experience in government, many cabinet decisions are overturned in the party room by aggressive and articulate backbenchers. Senators O'Chee and Macdonald were no exceptions in contributing to this time in government. An example of this was when the National Party senators, after several meetings with the Prime Minister in his office, were instrumental in achieving a better deal for the rural and regional areas in regard to the sale of Telstra.

On the personal side, both showed a personal quality in their commitment to family life. Sandy and his wife Alice have had three children during Sandy's term in parliament, and I have always admired the way he exudes love for his family. Recently married, Bill is especially admired for the example of spiritual strength he has brought to his family. These qualities of their private lives have inevitably flowed into public life, not just to benefit the party but to bring a better standing to the parliament. We on this side of the Senate will sorely miss their talents in the parliament. The rural and regional areas of Australia will miss their talents and they will miss two very strong voices. We in the National Party will miss their mateship. Vale, Sandy and Bill.

One other colleague is Karen Synon. As has been said, she has been here for a very short time, but I cannot say that I did not know her. Like Senator Abetz, I have known Karen since way back in my university days, which is many years ago now, when I was a Liberal. I am happy to say that. It was then that she took up the issue that she is involved in now, voluntary student unionism. Since the issue has hit the table in this parliament, she has produced very well researched material and has spoken like a seasoned campaigner and politician, maybe because she has been across the issue since her university days. I think it is a fair indicator of just how well she would have adapted to this parliament and how she would have tackled issues with vigour and skill, as she has with the VSU issue.

It is true to say that that was pretty obvious from the first day and her maiden speech. As Senator Crane said, very few maiden speeches around here are remembered—other than your own. But people refer back to your maiden speech; you access people's maiden speeches when you are doing these sorts of speeches. It is meant to be a gauge of who you are and what you represent. Regrettably, maiden speeches are not what they used to be, but Senator Synon's was, just that, a traditional maiden speech. She spoke then of a revolution—we were all quite stunned—and a seemingly very tough approach to social welfare. But in reality she was just slightly ahead of her time because, in this government, we have basically taken up that very philosophy which we have cloaked in the phrase of `mutual obligation', and which is very well accepted in the community. In fact, Senator Synon was talking about what is now a worldwide trend. In England we have Prime Minister Blair and in America we have President Clinton, both from the left side of politics, actually boasting about the tightening of budgets, the audit trails, the toughening of social welfare, the savings they have made and the mutual obligations that they have introduced. It is a worldwide trend, and Senator Synon's maiden speech picked up on that probably well before all of us got used to the idea.

Politics, as Senator Boswell said, has dealt her a bad hand. Regrettably, she has lost her preselection. It seems pretty tough that she should be selected one time and then unselected within 12 months—but that is not for me to comment on, just to watch, I suppose. She has always been a good National Party sympathiser but, more so than Karen, her husband has been a great National Party sympathiser. In fact, her husband, Joe, has always wanted amalgamation between the two parties. I am sorry, Joe, as long as Senator Boswell sits in that front seat, we are never going to get amalgamation. I wish Senator Synon well in her studies. I wish my two colleagues well and, of course, I extend my best wishes to all retiring senators. I wish Margaret Reynolds over there in the chamber the best retirement that she could possibly have.

talk.start.para: —In the three short years I have been here in the Senate, I have always been struck by the fact that the people who come here all come with sincere, if different, beliefs. They all have a great respect for the institution while they are here, and they all make valuable contributions to the deliberations of this chamber and to the affairs thereby of our country and nation. It is a great privilege to be a member of the Senate. One of the dimensions of that privilege is to meet the interesting people who become senators. They are a very interesting group of people, coming from very different political backgrounds and all parts of this great country of ours. I would like to make a few short remarks about some of my colleagues who are retiring tonight.

speech.para: Bill O'Chee, in the time I have been here, has always impressed me with his absolutely unmatched command of the English language. Bill O'Chee sitting around a dinner table can suddenly burst into a quotation of Shakespeare, Tolstoy or all sorts of great authors of the past and apply it to whatever the point of the conversation is. Bill is a man of great principle, and he showed that during the last election in the stand he took on the One Nation issue. He has paid a political price for what he did but, as has been said already tonight, he did something that had to be done for the dignity and strength of the Australian nation. I have the greatest respect for you and for the stand that you took, Bill.

People have spoken about you tonight as a Chinese Australian, but I believe, in fact, that your family has been in Australia for some five or even six generations. You are perhaps more Australian than almost everybody here in the parliament today. There has been a certain amount of comment about your waistcoats, dare I say, and your perhaps uncoordinated sense of colour. I have greatly admired your shirts, because I am a great collector of shirts. Your ties have been more modest and moderate than those of Senator McKiernan. I recall that once during a division he was wearing a particularly outlandish tie. As I walked by, I said, `Please reassure me, Jim, that your aunt gave you this tie.' He was unable to do that.

One thing that nobody has mentioned, Bill, is an area in which you will be sadly missed—that is, the dining room. You will be missed by the dining room staff in this parliament because I do not think there will be anybody else who orders a Coca Cola spider with every meal. Bill, it has been a great privilege to know you. I wish you well in the future. I am sure that, in whatever field you devote yourself to, you will be crowned with great success. It has been a privilege to know you in the Senate.

Sandy Macdonald is another person for whom I have the greatest respect. It has been said tonight that Sandy epitomises the gentleman farmer, and that he does. He is a very thoughtful man who thinks a great deal about issues. It has been said tonight that he is likely to return here in the not too distant future. I do not know whether or not that is the case, but I suppose it is an option that may be open to you, Sandy. If you do return, I am sure that you will make a very great contribution to the Senate and to this parliament over the years. If you do not come back, and if you go into other fields, I am sure, equally, you will make a great success of whatever else you choose to do. In any case, as has been said by others, it has been a great pleasure to know you. You truly are a gentleman.

David MacGibbon is a person I have known only in the twilight of his political career, but he is obviously a senator with huge experience. He has brought a great deal of grace and dignity to the Senate. I wish him well in his post-Senate endeavours. I know that he has a great interest in aviation and perhaps he will follow that line. I certainly wish David well.

Karen Synon, as has been said, is a senator who has been here only a very short time. She is someone whose gentle demeanour disguises the passions of her political beliefs. Karen is somebody who really knows what she believes in politically. She is here as somebody who has a definite point of view about how this country should be run. I am sure that, given her long involvement in the Victorian Liberal Party, Karen's political career will not be over on 30 June and this episode in the Senate at this time will be but a chapter in what I am sure will be a very long and perhaps distinguished political career. Karen, I wish you well in your future endeavours in the Liberal Party.

Dee Margetts is another person whom I would like to mention. Dee Margetts is a fellow Western Australian representing the environmental movement, which these days draws support from all quarters of the political spectrum. It is a very interesting thing that one finds that one's friends from the far Right to the far Left these days all care quite passionately about protecting the environment. I have found from working with Dee on committees that she always has a very focused point of view and she puts her questions concisely and has a definite objective in mind. I think in the end it must be said about Dee Margetts's time in the Senate that she certainly made a valuable contribution in pursuing her cause, and she must be respected for that.

I have really had very little to do with Senator Margaret Reynolds and Senator Mal Colston. I have only known Senator Margaret Reynolds in passing, but I must say my impressions coincide with all that has been said about her tonight, as a person who cares about human rights issues, as a thoroughly ladylike individual and somebody who, I believe, from all that has been said to me, has really made an outstanding contribution to this chamber over the years. I wish her every happiness in the future and a fruitful retirement.

In closing, I reiterate that one of the great pleasures and privileges of being in the Senate is to know the senators. They are an interesting, diverse, sincere and committed group of people. Those who are retiring tonight certainly are characteristic of that description. I wish them all success in the future.

talk.start.para: —I would like to add some words about retiring senators. I will spend slightly longer on those whom I have got to know and, obviously, less on those whom I know less. I want to start with David MacGibbon, because he was probably the first senator I ever got to know. He was a friend and colleague in medical circles in Brisbane, as mentioned by Senator Herron this evening. As a colleague and friend of my father's, I was drawn to David MacGibbon's entry into the Senate at that time. I was always passionately interested in federal politics, particularly the Senate, from a very young age. I obviously had a very misguided youth! I used to listen to the debates in the Senate endlessly through the 1980s.

speech.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It does, Senator Faulkner. It is probably why I am attracted to guillotines these days. I credit David MacGibbon with instilling in me a strong interest in defence. I formed a group called the Young Australia Defence League back in the 1980s to try and get young people interested in defence policy during that time. David has remained, throughout his career, someone who has had a detailed interest and knowledge in defence issues. I particularly thank David for giving me since I entered the Senate—he probably is not even aware of my interest in defence—helpful guidance from time to time on a range of issues. It was never pushed or forced on me. Since I have been Manager of Government Business in the Senate he has given me helpful, timely, unintrusive advice which I value incredibly highly—and far more highly than David will ever know.

speech.para: I think Bill O'Chee is a most incredible loss to the Senate. Bill was endorsed in Brisbane the day before I was endorsed in Perth. They were both casual vacancies. I met Bill a few days later when we both arrived in Canberra and I congratulated him because, in the Sunday Times newspaper in Perth, the story appeared that a 24-year-old had been elected. I was a 30-year-old at the time and it was regarded in the WA Liberal Party as being incredibly young to be entering the Senate. It was a hotly contested preselection, as Senator Eggleston will recall. Senator Lightfoot would also have been aware of it at the time. I think there was a field of 21 candidates running for the spot that was left vacant by Senator Chaney. To have this article appear in the Sunday Times saying that a 24-year-old had been endorsed in Brisbane made a 30-year-old in the WA Liberal Party look comparatively old. That is when I first got to know you.

We have served together as relatively young politicians for the past nine years and I regard that as an incredible privilege and honour. I know that whatever you do in the future will be a success, because in whatever you have done you have shown incredible commitment, thoroughness and stickability. You have always seen things through and you understand what you deal with. Whenever we dealt with things together we could always be assured that you had done it thoroughly. I am sure all of the constituents that you have helped—and there must be thousands by now—know that you have looked after them and got great results.

My dad, whom I refer to again, had the pleasure of meeting you at Roma at a cattle sale. He had obviously heard of you through the telegraph wire that runs between Queensland and Western Australia. He had an image of a National Party senator, and he said that you did not match it, and I guess it is what everyone has been saying about your clothes. He said he was incredibly impressed to see this relatively young man wearing R.M. Williams moleskins, R.M. Williams boots, colourful shirts and ties and a big hat—which my dad said did not seem to go together—but you seemed to have all the people at the cattle auction in the palm of your hand. They were very interested in talking to you, and my father came home very impressed.

Bill, I am sure that, whatever you turn your hand at, you will be a success. I, selfishly from the coalition's point of view, would love to see you come back here. You may well be far too intelligent, too bright and probably care too much for Tara and Rory to consider coming back here again, but I really hope you do. It is great to see the Leader of the National Party here care so deeply about your career and your life; it is great to see Senator Boswell's support for you. I do hope that the wise men and wise women in the National Party—and I am sure there are many in Queensland—do see what an incredible loss you are to the coalition and to conservative forces in Australia, and that you do, after some time and some consideration, try to come back into politics because I think you still have an enormous contribution to make.

The last thing I wanted to say to you here, Bill—I am sure we will say things privately from time to time and I do hope we can keep in touch—is that I was listening to a speech that George W. Bush Jr made on 24 March, I think, when he announced the formation of his exploratory committee to run for the President of United States. One of the journalists at the press conference asked the Governor of Texas about the legacy of his father's policies and whether or not he would have to wear them in his presidential campaign. The Governor sought to distinguish the difference between his father's policies as President and his own in the most diplomatic way—and we are all diplomatic like that when we need to differentiate ourselves in politics.

One of the most incredibly touching things that the Governor said—and I know you are an Internet person, Bill, and you can see the speech on videostream at www.georgewbush.com—was that his dad had done his most important thing in life very, very well, and that was being a father. Bill, you have the great honour of being the father to a new son. As someone who, like Sandy Macdonald, has become the very proud father of three children since coming into the Senate, I can assure you that being a husband to Tara and a father to Rory is the most import ant job you will have and I know you will do that very well as well. So you have my best wishes, Bill, for all you do.

I met Sandy Macdonald when he came into the Senate, but we have not served on committees together. He always seems to be busy doing things and I am too. Every now and again, we get a chance to chat down at Lee's over a bit of Chinese or on a plane, but I have always thought Sandy Macdonald would rise to the very highest ranks in politics here in Australia. I was incredibly shocked and disappointed when he lost his seat in the Senate.

I really hope that all of these rumours about Sandy just slipping so easily back in the Senate do prove true. I am sure nothing is that easy in politics; it is never that easy to get into the Senate. As our leader said to us earlier, virtually anyone who gets here has been very dedicated and committed and believed in something and worked hard to get here. Sandy, I hope it is as easy as everyone is saying. I am sure it is not, but I do hope you come back.

I still believe you can make it to the very top of politics in Australia and, from what I have seen of you, your contribution would be very welcome and needed in Australia, where we have so much more work to do on building this economy, making it strong and taking our place in the world proudly. You can be very proud of what has been achieved in your relatively short time here. I think in the major capital cities of Australia—particularly Sydney and Melbourne, where there is such a congregation of seats in the House of Representatives—there is an incredibly sad lack of understanding of the foundations of the Australian economy.

We have some fantastic new economies building. The Internet economy, the e-commerce sectors of it and the services sectors are very great new sectors. But we still have this incredibly important rural industry—the mining sector, the oil sector. The country's exports and its economic strength still depend on that. If we forget that, if the people in the major cities do not understand that, we will be at great risk. So your contribution as a seasoned rural senator is going to be a great loss.

I only met Karen Synon when she came into the Senate. I do not have the benefit of Senator Abetz's long association with you, Karen. I share Senator Chris Ellison's sentiments entirely in your bringing new vigour and passion back into the debate and the fight for voluntary student unionism. Although I have known you only in the time since you have been here—and your husband Joe, whom I recognise in the gallery—we have obviously been soul mates for a couple of decades. As you know very well, I have been fighting for voluntary student unionism from my very earliest days on campus at the WA Institute of Technology, in the Young Liberal Movement and in the Liberal Party.

In Western Australia, through the determination of Norman Frederick Moore, the then Minister for Education, we had introduced into that state under the Court Liberal government true voluntary student unionism. So young Western Australians, or anyone else from Australia or overseas can actually attend a university in Western Australia now—I think we are into our fifth academic year—and not be forced to join a union against their will. Nor are they forced to pay this thing called an amenities and services fee, or whatever they happen to call it in those places that think they like a bit of voluntarism but are not quite sure. So they take this sort of weak, halfway house position and say, `We'll just compel you all to pay the fee but you don't have to join the union.' It is a gutless and hopeless middle road. A young Australian, 17 or 18 years old, can walk into a campus, be made an offer to join the student union and can make a reasoned judgment as to whether or not they would like to join—like most other things they do in life. But some people believe that we had better not give them that much freedom—just a little bit of freedom.

Karen, it has been fantastic for you to come here and reinvigorate that policy. It was a policy we took to the 1996 election. It is a policy that is enshrined in a bill that is actually on the Senate Notice Paper today. If we can get that bill through by close of business on 30 June, we owe you more than anyone else here at the moment.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There are a few little hurdles to get that one through, Senator Faulkner, as you know. But, if we do get it through, it will be in no small part due to Senator Synon's contribution.

speech.para: I say to Senator Colston, whose vote will be needed to get that legislation through, that it would be an incredible contribution if he was able to support that before 30 June and deliver, as Senator Abetz has said, that freedom to hundreds of thousands of students who should have it right across Australia. To live in 1999 in Australia and have to go up to a vice-chancellor and say, `I want to be a conscientious objector,' as if it is conscription, because it is conscription, is appalling.

Karen, it has been a pleasure to work alongside you on that legislation. If we cannot get it through before 30 June, you can rest assured—and I know you will—that we will continue fighting for it. I hope that you will carry on the fight in Victoria for this so that one day Victoria has voluntary student unionism. It is quite amazing that it does not have it after all these years. I hope that it does get it one day so that Victorians can have that same freedom.

Karen, you are, to use again a term coined by the Governor of Texas, a compassionate conservative, but you are a passionate conservative. When Newt Gingrich gave his final speech at GOPAC after he resigned as Speaker of the US Congress, he said he intended to go on and continue public service in another way. You will do that with your long record of public service already.

I will conclude quickly by saying that I think Margaret Reynolds has been an absolute role model of a senator. Regardless of what sex you are, I have been absolutely inspired by working opposite you. We have taken different views on very emotive issues such as Aboriginal affairs—we have some very different views on that—but I have massive respect for Senator Reynolds for the way that she carries on the debate. Even when we disagree passionately about something, she is a true lady. I hope my daughter grows up to be just like you, Senator Reynolds; I hope she is as much a lady as you are.

Senator Dee Margetts I have had to deal with regularly on matters to do with management of government business. Her leaving will make my life far less interesting, but I wish her well. As Manager of Government Business, I have had to deal with Senator Colston, and I have found him to be nothing other than truly honourable and a gentleman. I hope his health improves; I hope he has a much longer life and that his children enjoy their father. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I am very pleased to see that you have come into the chair because, as I look around at the faces in this parliament tonight, I think there is only one face other than your own that was here when I first entered in 1983.

speech.para: Senator Watson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I beg your pardon, Senator Watson; it is a little late in the evening. But, of course, we were not in this building; we were in the old Parliament House. Much as I love this building for many reasons, I do not know that we have the same sort of conviviality that we had in that closer environment. We used to meet in all sorts of unlikely places, and I think it did bring a greater sense of comradeship than this vast building, where sometimes I cannot even get around to seeing colleagues on my side of the chamber in the other place just because of distance and a variety of commitments.

speech.para: What has struck me about tonight's debate is how frequently people have referred to first speeches. I suppose that in a valedictory debate the things of which you are most aware are how well behaved everybody is and how people are very generous in their comments—and I thank you for those comments. I think it is a pity that we cannot extend the behaviour shown with first speeches and valedictory speeches to all the time in this place. However, I am sure that is being far too idealistic and I, myself, am guilty of calling out, interjecting—even of the term that has been adopted recently, `sledging'.

I would like to take this opportunity to wish all retiring senators the very best for the future. I am sorry that some of you have not chosen to go. I feel very fortunate and privileged in the sense that for my political career I have had a wonderful 16 years and yet I have been able to choose this as the time for me to move on. Not only is it time for me to move on, but also it is time for a younger person to come in, and I am sure you will all enjoy the contribution of my successor, Jan McLucas, from Cairns.

I would like particularly to endorse the comments that were made by Senator Boswell about Bill O'Chee. That praise that has been given not just by Ron Boswell but by a number of honourable senators is very well earned, Bill—and I think we can be familiar this evening without anyone taking a point of order. Your stand was very strong, very committed and personal when you took on One Nation and spoke out frequently about racism and intolerance. Senators from Queensland and those who have visited that state and know a little bit about it will know also that it is not easy to take strong stands in a state that is very diverse. It does have a wide range of viewpoints, and that is the great thing about the Australian democracy—that we do tolerate a wide range of viewpoints. But it is not easy to speak out as Senator O'Chee did—and, indeed, as Senator Boswell has done in terms of his absolute rejection and condemnation of the League of Rights.

I would also like to wish Senator David MacGibbon and Senator Sandy Macdonald all the very best for their futures. I hear that Senator Macdonald will be returning, and I certainly hope that that is the case. I think all the comments that have been made tonight indicate that he would be very much welcomed back.

Senator Synon, we do not know each other very well, but I can really relate to what has happened to you in your political career in 1999 because it so very nearly happened to me in 1984. I was very fortunate at that time in that I did somehow manage to retain my position on the Senate ticket. In fact, I was actually pushed up into the No. 1 position to make sure that nothing could happen in terms of my being moved down the ticket. I know how disappointing it must be for you, having just established your career in this place. But, as other senators have said, I am sure there will be another time and another place, whether it is this place or the Victorian parliament.

I must say that, considering that occasion when I did manage to retain my position on the Queensland Senate ticket, when there was a lot of controversy about whether or not I should be returned or somebody else should come in my place, I like to boast—and I do not know whether there is anyone here at the moment who would object to my doing so—that I must be one of the few people who actually managed to get the better of the Australia Workers Union in Queensland. It is an idle boast I can make now, being so close to the end of my political career. I have to say that I have many friends and supporters in the Australian Workers Union, but at that time there were critics who were determined to take my position.

To my friend Dee Margetts: I wish there were more politicians like you—totally independent, strong minded and compassionate in your advocacy. In the Australian political scene there is a reluctance to admire independence of spirit. For instance, in the Westminster system and certainly in the US Congress, it is not unusual for political parties to find that they are criticised, or even that people cross the floor.

That is not the tradition of my party. Some of us have commented on this on a number of occasions, but sooner or later that tradition will change to give a little more independence. That is not to say that there should not be a loyalty to one's party or the group that is responsible for one's election, and obviously that loyalty must come first. But sometimes there is a place for that ability to cross the floor on certain issues. Of course, I cannot help but comment that there are just two issues where that right is given, and that is in relation to abortion and euthanasia. I think it should be extended to a number of other moral and ethical issues.

talk.start.para: —You could come over and vote with us on the GST, Margaret.

—No, that is a policy issue. I am very happy to stick with my party on that, thank you. I thought tonight was an appropriate occasion to say—late as it is, and I thank the Senate for some indulgence—that my first impression of the Senate was in 1975, which must seem many years ago to someone of Bill O'Chee's generation. I came to visit a number of members and senators in the old parliament. I had dinner and then I was taken up into the gallery to view the parliament.

speech.para: I have to confess that I did not know very much about politics in those days. I looked down and my lasting impression was of men dozing and they all seemed to be bald, although I should not identify a physical characteristic. I am not baldist, I assure you. They were either asleep or reading newspapers, and there were so few of them. I thought, `Is this democracy at work?'

In 1983 I came back to the parliament and there had been quite a significant change. For a start, Madam President, you were here, along with Margaret Guilfoyle, Flo Bjelke-Petersen and a number of my other wonderful colleagues, Olive Zakharov, Rose Crowley, Pat Giles and, of course, Susan Ryan. But at that time there was still a very predictable male atmosphere about the place. Most nights that I can remember people automatically went to the bar. It was the obvious place to go before dinner, during dinner and probably after dinner. It was a very different atmosphere.

Now as I look around I see that the parliament has changed out of all recognition. It is young, diverse and very active. I am sure we all get the opportunity to have a drink or two over a meal, but we do not have time to go to any bar, unless of course we have one in our offices. This is what breaks down some of the social camaraderie, because people do tend to remain in their offices more.

Senator Margetts asked, `Have I achieved what I set out to?' and I thought I should ask myself the same question. I am afraid that my answer would be fairly typical of a politician because I would say, `Yes and no.' Yes, I have, in that I have been part of two periods of reformist government, the Hawke and Keating governments. I was part of a number of very far-reaching social policy reforms.

I am not going to take the risk in terms of behaviour in the chamber tonight by outlining them, nor contrasting them with policy today. But what I would say—and this is why I give that half-hearted answer, yes and no—is that whatever was achieved, there still remains so much to be done. In that way I would like to say that one of the most important things for the Australian democracy is that we do so much more to communicate what we are about, why we are here and where we think we can change the lives of Australians for the better.

Communication is not the skill of most of us in parliament. Why is it so difficult to get the messages through when we feel so strongly? Is it because the media wants to report the sensational? Is it because we have to rely on the public service to actually deliver on our ideals? Whatever it is, I am taking that task to the department of government to teach politics and international relations. I hope through doing that that I can make young people a little bit more committed to their democracy and value it.

In conclusion, Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to recognise all the unsung heroes of this parliament. There are so many unsung heroes in the parliament and they are not the elected unsung heroes. Certainly tonight, we have got more than our fair share of recognition. First of all I would like to recognise in the Department of the Senate, Harry Evans, Anne Lynch and their team. Because I am a temporary chair of committees, I have decided that they are a little bit like the wise monkeys. They sit there, they see no evil—although sometimes they do—they speak no evil and they hear no evil. They remind those of us who are taking the Senate through its paces where there is a breach of standing orders, and they tell us when there is unparliamentary language.

I am just waiting, Madam President, for the day when they run out of patience, stand up and demand order. We only have to deal with it for a short time, although you, Madam President, have to deal with it for much longer than those of us in temporary positions. But the officers of the Senate have to sit through it all, all day, every day, and I think that one day they may find the role of the three wise monkeys just too much and they might say what they are really thinking. That would be a terrible shock to all of us.

I would also like to take this opportunity to recognise Hansard. Hansard is similar in that they have to listen to it all and record it all. They have to have the patience to make sense of it all. I have only ever had one real dispute with Hansard. I know there was a dispute that my friend Rose Crowley mentioned earlier, but I did have a dispute very early in my political career when I made my first speech. As you would understand, Senator Macdonald, there were a number of references to North Queensland. I got the draft and there were capitals—no capitals for north, no capitals for Queensland. It was just in lower case. I really had quite a dispute at the time and said, `Look, the north of Queensland is a distinct region. I want capital letters.'

Another unsung hero of this parliament that I would like to recognise is the Parliamentary Education Office. That office does an absolutely magnificent job for us all. We are all aware of it. We visit it. We visit the students from our states, but I wonder if we genuinely appreciate just how much they are sowing the seeds of recognition of our democratic process in the wonderful work that they do.

The next group that I would like to mention is the Parliamentary Library. Again, they are unsung heroes for the issues papers, research and responses that they give so quickly. You can ring them and say, `Look, I am sorry it is quite urgent.' They ask, `When would you like it? Would 2 o'clock be okay?', and there will always be some information ready for you.

I have special praise for the Senate printer. I have a wonderful staff member here in Canberra, Jean Willoughby, who has a background in the preparation of documents. Between Jean Willoughby and the Senate printer we have been able to produce a number of very worthwhile contributions to policy debate. Madam President, I sent you one just recently. It is the first time ever a publication has been issued about the commitment of Commonwealth countries to human rights education. That came about as a result of my membership of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and the fact that the document was able to be printed here in the Senate.

I have to recognise Comcar and, like so many others, I have to say that I wish it was as it used to be. I think it is a tragedy that we have lost so many skilled and caring drivers. It was a wonderful service. I think the time will come—I hope it comes soon—when many people will realise that we have to rebuild that particular service. It was a service to members and senators and their families, and to senior public servants and Veterans' Affairs. It is still there, but only just. I really hope that someone can take up the fight to ensure that they get their due recognition.

I would like to thank Jetset, Qantas and Ansett. No matter what my itinerary has been over 16 years, they have always been able to handle it. I cancel, I change my arrangements, I juggle flights. Most people would just throw up their hands in horror, but I have always found the airlines and Jetset to be very patient and very competent.

I must thank the attendants. I thank Aussie's; where would we be without the cappuccino every few hours or so? Last of all, there are the unsung heroes who often are not mentioned in this place. Recently I did a study of who mentions their families in first speeches or, indeed, in valedictory speeches. Tonight it has been interesting that the focus has been on fathers and their contribution and commitment to their families, whereas traditionally it has been mothers and their contribution. It shows that we have seen a lot of change over my 16 years in parliament. We do talk about dual parenting and equal responsibility.

On that note, could I just tell one small anecdote which relates to my early months in this place. As Senator Schacht said, I did come in quite unexpectedly—unexpectedly for me. I had ambition—what parliamentarian doesn't—but I did not think my turn would come as soon as it did. At the time I had a 10-year-old daughter. I thought, `What will I do?' Yes, she had her big sister, her father and her grandmother on the premises at home, but it seemed important that she understand what I was coming to do. So she came here with me. Down she came and was enrolled at the Red Hill school, and every afternoon she would jump on the bus, come into Old Parliament House and make friends with all the attendants—and particularly with Flo Bjelke-Petersen, who always had something much more appealing for afternoon tea than Rebecca's mother had.

In those days, Madam President, we used to sit some terrible hours, didn't we. We used to sit not just as we are tonight because I am still talking, but it was nothing to be still debating legislation at 3 o'clock in the morning. Rebecca would sleep on a doona, with another one over her, on the floor of my little office in the Old Parliament House. When it was time to go home, she would trundle up, get in the car and we would go home. I think some people thought I was absolutely mad and that she would turn out to be a wild delinquent and I would regret it. Happily, I can say that she did not, and has not. But it does remind us that, all these years later, we still do not have permanent child care, long day care, in this place. I have to say that the fault is not one that I will necessarily lay at the feet of this government—though, as you know, I may lay many faults at the feet of this government.

talk.start.para: —You had 13 years in which to do it.

—Yes, exactly—and it was a certain finance minister, whose name I forget. But there has not been commitment to change policy in that direction over those 16 years. I hope that, with the Minister for Sport and Tourism, Jackie Kelly, announcing that she is expecting next year, that policy may change in the very near future. Thank you very much and I wish you all the best.
