—One of the finest honours which can be enjoyed by any Australian citizen is the honour and privilege of being a member of the Senate in the parliament of Australia, to sit here within these walls, to debate the great events of the day, to lay down our visions for the future. It is a great honour because, on top of the high office, we enjoy two things. The first is that we are the heirs and the legatees of all that has gone before us. We are the custodians of the hopes and the dreams of this precious land. And it is not ours to keep, to do with as we want. It is ours to vouchsafe, in that short period when we are here, and to pass on to those that follow. To that I shall return shortly.

speech.para: The other great reason we are privileged is the immense service that we enjoy as senators which we sometimes, or frequently, take for granted. I believe it appropriate to begin by thanking the people who give their service to us. I start with my personal staff, a small band of people who have always been to me immensely loyal, immensely dedicated, and on whom I could rely at any time to fulfil any request. It has been a privilege to work with them, and I thank them all.

To the staff of the parliament, the chamber attendants, who are here long after we leave, the gym staff, the clerks, the cleaners, the printers and, never let us forget, the staff of the dining room, and dear Kate, and all the things that are done for us by those people so that our life and our work might be little easier: for them, too, we must have thanks and praise—and to the people who support us in Queensland and in our electorates, to the Comcar drivers, to all the people that try to help us do a good job for Australia.

Then, on a personal note, I want to thank my friends outside this building, the people who put in perspective all the things that we enjoy, my friends at the Institute of Sport, my friends from before I came into politics and the friends that I have made whilst I have been in politics. To that, too, I add my colleagues, my coalition colleagues and, in particular, my National Party colleagues, a group of people here in this end of the chamber that Shakespeare must have been thinking about 500 years ago when he wrote those words:
We few, we happy few, we band of brothers . . .

To Ron, to Grant, to David, to Julian and to Sandy in particular: I have enjoyed immensely the privilege of working with you and of being one of your brothers in our shared ambitions for what can be for rural and regional Australia. And to all the senators here: it is a great privilege to work here, it is a great privilege to enjoy debate across the chamber and conviviality and shared dreams and talk of what might be.

I should make mention of those who depart but I want to do it very briefly, not because I do not value them, but because there are other things I want to say tonight. In Margaret, Karen, and Dee Margetts we have three fine Australian women with different ambitions, but each has pursued them with vigour, with enthusiasm and with a fervent belief that what they were doing made the country better. That is the service, the high service, that you have bestowed on your country and it has been a great pleasure to work with you and to watch you pursue your goals.

To Mal Colston I owe an immense degree of thanks for his loyalty and support on the Regulations and Ordinances Committee where, as many senators would know, he has worked tirelessly for years and years. Of David MacGibbon I say that defence has probably rarely had a finer advocate in this place than David but that David's talents and skills range far beyond that. He has always been a steadying influence, sometimes in rocky days, for the coalition.

Finally, for Sandy Macdonald, my very dear friend, my conspirator sometimes in the mutual league of trouble, but undoubtedly a great Australian and a man I admire immensely, a man that sometimes I wish I could be like. But I doubt, Sandy, that I will ever reach the pinnacle of integrity that you exemplify in this place.

My final word of thanks is my most important and it is to my wife who has put up with me for so many years and only occasionally has relented. She has been an immense aid to me. She has helped me grow and become a better person and has given us a wonderful son. One of the great things in life, as Senator Ian Campbell has said, is the opportunity to be a good parent, and I look forward to the opportunity of spending much more time with Tara and with Rory and to helping him grow and develop and be a fine person.

I want to return to another theme, and that is the theme of Australia, because that is why we are here. We are here charged with an obligation to care for the country which we have inherited. I want to make a few observations about this country. This ancient continent which we now call Australia was first populated by Aboriginal and islander people who, along with their forebears, inhabited the land for thousands of years. They were followed by people from the British Isles, by convicts, gaolers and later free men and free women who, disdaining tyranny and loving freedom, triumphed over humble beginnings to create a sovereign and independent nation in which democracy and equality of rule now flourish. That was their achievement.

To our shores have come countless thousands more from many lands who have shed the enmities of old, who have united in the belief that while ever our nation stands, freedom and happiness, justice and opportunity shall never perish from the face of this earth. It is to that that we are the heirs and the legatees.

I believe that the government of Australia requires of its parliamentarians four things, four foundations of service. They are: truth, principle, fearlessness and a vision for the common good. Truth, the first and one of the most important, is the wellspring from which every moral judgment we make comes. Without truth, there can be no moral judgments because there is no fact upon which to weigh our deliberations. It impels upon us an obligation to serve the truth, to tell the truth, to seek out the truth and never to fear the truth. When you fear the truth, you bring in weakness; you undermine your moral mandate.

From truth flows principle. What is the purpose of being in parliament if we only serve power and do not serve principle? That would be to rob from the people who sent us here the moral imperative which we enjoy. They send us here, no matter what our party, in the belief that we are men and women of principle, and will serve them faithfully. So you have to form your own views, your own principles, and you have to remain true to them; and they have to be consistent and they have to flow like a theme through your life, like a river through a valley. Without it, you are nothing. And with it, you are incredibly powerful.

Then, to add to those two things, you require fearlessness. Fearlessness is most important of all: to stand up, to state what you believe is right when it would be so easy to do what is popular; to withstand the assault of people who say that you are not a representative, that you do not care for their wishes, when you care passionately for what you can do for them. I hope and pray that all of you who remain, and those who follow, will be blessed with infinite amounts of fearlessness, because that is what our country needs. It is your fearlessness that returns the duty of fearlessness which was given by other Australians, in places far less salubrious than this, who had the fearlessness to lay down their lives for what we enjoy today. Therefore, how much less do we ask that we should lay aside popularity to keep faith with those who have laid down their lives.

We must have a vision for the common good. That does not mean our sectoral interests, but we have to always ask: what is it that we can do which everybody will support, which will bring our nation together? That requires imagination. It requires enthusiasm. It requires give and take. It requires maturity. I know that the people in this chamber and in the other place have those qualities. When I leave this place, as an Australian and as a voter I will pray that you will always seek the common good, and advance this nation as much as we can.

Finally, we should be willing to see that there is a world outside these shores. It is not good enough for us merely to say that this is a lucky country and that we are going to preserve it. It has always been the case that Australians who have gone before us have believed in this country so much that they have been willing to take the best of what we had and give it to the rest of the world. We have gone through a tough time. Economically, we have gone through a time in which we had to mend, a time to heal, a time to succour. But now is a time to rise up and, with enthusiasm, create a region of the world whose dreams, whose aspirations and whose hopes are forged in the image of our own lucky country, to give to the rest of the world, to people less fortunate than we, the great privileges and luxuries that we have in this democracy. And above it all is the rule of law. We have always to understand that we are the servants of the law, not the masters of it. We may make it, but we are still subordinate to it. That is a quality which is only found in democracies, and even then only rarely.

I know my colleagues are getting tired so I wish to conclude. I said at the beginning that this nation was founded on a dream, a dream of greatness, and of what free men and free women could achieve when loosed from the bondage of the old world. And the flame of that dream still burns now. It comes glimmering to us through the mists of time. It was the light our Anzacs saw that first dawn on Gallipoli Peninsula. It illuminated the dark despair of Changi and Hellfire Pass. That light still falls on graves of Australians who rest overseas from the service of their country. And we see it today in the hopes of the man on the land and the gentle ways of the country towns.

It shines to us in our children's smiles, in their eager eyes, their simple joys. Most importantly, it is a tribute to the greatness of our forebears, to ideals which endure the smallness and meanness of lesser struggles and which bestow on each and every Australian a glory that will never fade so long as this world rolls around and we are its worthy servants.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, earlier today I read my first speech for the first time in six years. Some of it is still relevant, some of it is a little dated, but mostly it was a speech of somebody who had not experienced the incredible opportunity and experience of being a member of this Senate. The ability to help people, to have access to almost anybody in pursuit of that, the oppor tunity to have an influence—albeit it small—on national and international affairs, and a chance to know well people on both sides of politics who come from many different directions but find themselves bound together working for a better Australia.

speech.para: In many ways I found my time here a very chastening experience. It is always interesting the things that really affect you. In my first speech I quoted The Man from Snowy River as an example of what I thought of the exciting prospect of public life. I imagined it might be a roller-coaster but that there would be a certain order about it; that I would be a backbencher; that I would be part of a government; that I would get my hands on the levers, whether they be big or small; that I would leave this place of my own volition or when my party indicated the game was up.

I certainly do not agree with Enoch Powell's cynical view of politics when he says that all politicians leave as failures, but certainly political careers do not turn out as you might expect. To be perfectly honest what we most crave is the respect of our peers. So personal success in politics is realistically a very narrow gauge of worth or what your time in public life can mean.
It was brought home to me especially last year at the funeral of John and Julia Anderson's little boy, Andrew, and it came from a verse of The Servant's Hymn which says:
We are pilgrims on a journey;
We are brothers on the road;
We are here to help each other
To walk the mile and share the load

We should not forget that all of us lucky enough to be elected to this place are on a journey to make our abundant country a more abundant place, and we should never forget the privilege of that because that in itself is an end.

Madam President, personalities and personal friendships are very important in this place and, as somebody with a very catholic taste in people, I made friends right across the political spectrum, brought about frequently by having the opportunity to travel and to serve on committees with a variety of senators and members. It is very important for the future of political debate in our country that all political parties have decent people, and I certainly will not embarrass some of my political opponents by identifying them as friends, but they know who they are. I wish them exceptionally well on a personal level, but not so well that their team gets control of the treasury benches for a long time. When and if Labor has earned the right to govern again, it will do so. Labor's continuing pursuit of political opportunism, whether it be in tax reform or the sale of Telstra or in other policies that many of them can see privately would be the correct course of action for Australia, will prevent them from earning that right.

In tax reform, the Labor Party knows the present tax system needs repair but at the last election when they had the chance to argue our package in the marketplace, filling in the possible vacuums in any change as big as this, they opposed it when many—almost all—in their heart of hearts acknowledge the need for a consumption tax and a change at least to our tax base. They would also acknowledge that when they next come to power they will inherit a much fairer tax system which has the additional benefit of federal-state financial cooperation.

Labor's simple opposition to tax reform has let Australia down—simple political advantage to them, yes, but it was wrong. Simple opposition to anything in politics generally lets you or your supporters down. A very early lesson for me was in 1993, which was referred to earlier, with the Mabo legislation. The Senate will recall that Dr Hewson simply opposed the legislation by saying, `When we get into government, we will simply fix it or repeal it.' That of course was never a practical solution and could not happen.

Part of the reason for the subsequent Wik litigation was that the original Mabo legislation was inadequate—all sides of politics acknowledge that—but which might have been fixed if the then opposition had amended it wisely. At that time, I crossed the floor with Senators O'Chee and McGauran in an attempt in a small way to improve just that, by securing the rights of pastoral leaseholders where there was a question of co-existence of native title. This in fact was one of the Labor government's amendments which, if it had been passed at that time, would have avoided one of the most contentious aspects of the Wik legislation last year. This is really ironic. Most people have forgotten it, but I never will.

I admit that my side of politics was wrong in 1993 to oppose native title outright, but Labor returned the compliment last year in spades. They let Australia down at that time and took considerable political advantage from the government's difficulties in passing legislation that was balanced and fair to all parties. This sort of humbug is not missed by your average person when they assess the performance of politicians. You might have noticed that I have used the word `humbug' and not `hypocrisy', which is a word used endlessly by politicians criticising their opponents. Hansard will recall it is a word I have never used in this place in the six years that I have been here, because politics in the broad is about people with very opposing views finding a compromise, one that frequently they are both happy with at the end of the day. To meet the needs of compromise in politics is not hypocritical but commonsense, and commonsense is a very good measure for political outcomes.

It is only natural that people ask how I feel about leaving the Senate. The answer is not hard to guess. On one side, like of all us here, I have a lot of effort and resources tied up in a political career and, through no fault of my own, with every expectation of some advancement if we had been returned to government, which we were, I was voted out because of the Pauline Hanson phenomena. Almost none of the nine per cent of New South Wales voters who voted in protest to Mrs Hanson would have realised that this haemorrhage of coalition votes would mean that a Democrat would come up the middle. But I do wish Senator-elect Ridgeway well in that regard. On the other side, I am not worried about the release from the responsibilities of public life, hopefully and perhaps not forever. I am very lucky to have a young family, a life outside politics, and I look forward to spending more time with my local community.

I am sure a lot of my fellow senators will understand this view—that is, when I went into politics I was somebody who played an active part in my local community. After six years in the Senate, I merely come home to sleep. This is not a criticism; it is just purely a fact of life. I certainly look forward to seeing my friends again. I am always reminded of a story about Bert Kelly who said that when he was elected to parliament he became a very important person in his local community. He said, `When I planted wheat, my neighbours planted wheat. When I bought sheep, my neighbours bought sheep. But, after I had been in politics a little while,' he said, `when I sold my cows, my neighbours bought them.'

Now to a couple of asides about my six years of coming to Canberra. It was three years before I was invited into a private house in Canberra. I am not complaining because we come here to work, but it is incredible that a gregarious person can spend that length of time in our national capital, a city of more than 300,000 people, and have virtually no social contact with the locals. The other thing that I have done is that I have never locked my Parliament House office. Somehow the thought of locking my office in this wonderful building affronts me.

In the broad, all of us participate in the four roles of the Senate. Firstly, we are an integral part of the government's legislative program. Everything must be passed by the Senate. As backbenchers, if we are honest, few of us get much satisfaction from this primary role, although we do have some say through our party and committee arrangements. Secondly, we review government process and make government accountable through the Senate's committee system and estimates. This area does provide enormous stimulation and the acquisition of knowledge to all of us. I have valued that and especially my chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. On committee service, like all of us, I have gone places and met people that most people just dream of. To be an official observer just two weeks ago at the Indonesian election—the first one for 44 years—was just one of those privileges. To go to the Menin Gate in 1996 was one of the highlights of my life.

Thirdly, we are here to help people over a whole array of electoral responsibilities. Our access as senators to people who make decisions is an extremely powerful weapon to assist. We all have stories that might appear mundane but where a mere phone call from us can change a person's life for the better. We all have examples of success stories that bring tears to the eyes of even the most cynical of people. This particular capacity to help is an area that I have found extremely stimulating. Lastly, of course, we are here because we represent our party and therefore we must nourish our members and our structures because, for better or for worse, parties make up a very large part of our democratic process and system.

I thank the National Party for the opportunity to serve them. I hope I have given them and the Australian taxpayers value for money. I have tried to be honest and I have always tried to say it the way I have seen it. I was given some advice before I came into the Senate by somebody who actually had been a longstanding member of one of our large statutory boards, the Australian Wheat Board, in those days. He said, `In public life, you won't always find it easy to tell people exactly what they have to be told. One bit of advice is that, when you come home at night, you want to look at yourself in the mirror and you want to minimise the number of nights where you do not see a very pretty sight.' I have tried to do that. I have always tried to be honest. It was good advice and I have tried to keep it.

Now a word about my colleagues. Almost without exception they are decent people trying to do the right thing. My National Party colleagues both here and in the House of Representatives are a good team and work extremely hard for their constituents within the constraints of coalition. I thank Senators Brownhill, Tambling, McGauran and O'Chee for their friendship and support. I leave this Senate in the very good company of Senator Bill O'Chee. As many other senators have said, he brought colour—I could say movement—and flair to this place. He has been, as you could all appreciate this evening, one of the great and best speech makers in this place. He is an exceptionally clever person. Bill does not speak or read Mandarin, but he is near fluent in German. Having sat beside him for six years, you were never quite sure what he was going to be doing next. He was especially keen on his German when he had a German girlfriend. That was a long time before he met Tara, when he used to spend a lot of question time working out appropriate words and phrases in German. I wish Bill and his wife, Tara, and son, Rory, all the fortune and happiness that they deserve.

I also wish the best to other senators departing—to Senator Reynolds, Senator Margetts and particularly my colleagues Senator MacGibbon and Senator Synon. Both of them are good friends of mine—one of them had a very long career and one had a very truncated career that we have heard about tonight, and I do feel for you, Karen, very much. I have enjoyed our time together, especially our trip to Indonesia. It was a great privilege for both of us. You can be sure to take some comfort from the fact you have added to the rich fabric of this great democracy that is our Australia.

I also thank my Liberal colleagues, especially Senator Hill. I am tempted to name all my Liberal colleagues who are my friends, but there are too many. To those who did not know me well, I am sorry. I have got a lot of friendships among the Liberal Party and I do value that. I thank my Canberra doctor, Senator Eggleston. I especially also thank you, Madam President, and your husband, Tom. You have been particularly generous to Alice and me.

My biggest thanks goes to Senator Boswell, our leader in the Senate. I always thought I would have the chance to say a few words about Bos when he left the Senate, but I am doing it because I am leaving. His experience in life and business has made it possible for him always to be on the side of the angels. Nobody can guess what he does for people, and we all know what a wonderful turn of phrase he has.

I can remember when I first came to Canberra, he said, `If you want a friend here, mate, bring a dog.' He said, `I've done more for you, than your mother has. She only carried you for nine months.' And, `A lot more people have talked themselves out of politics than into politics.' When we are particularly annoyed at Senator Faulkner, he says, `The ones that the gods wish to destroy, they first make mad.' We all love Bos. We worry about him and he says, `Don't worry about me. Any fitter and I'd be playing for the Broncos.' As a person, I look up to Bos and I think one of the unfortunate things of age is that, the older you get, the less opportunity you have to look up to people. I look up to him. We have always joked that he was about to be rolled as our leader, to which his reply always was, `Uneasy is the head that wears the crown.' So I thank all my coalition colleagues for their comradeship, but I especially thank Bos. I also thank Ian Sinclair, a most remarkable person for his wonderful company and guidance for my whole Senate term.

I would like to thank my staff, present and past—Helen Freestone, Meredith McKenzie, Fiona Hobden, Martine Whitton, Beth Black, Katherine Martin, Kerri Swain, Scott McFarlane and especially Gaye White, who has made a great success of her life and who provided me with exceptional wise counsel for the whole six years I have been in the Senate. My staff have all been loyal and intelligent people, and I have been fortunate indeed to have their support and friendship. Ours has always been an office full of gossip and humour.

I want to thank all the people who make the Senate work. The Comcar drivers, the Clerk and his assistants, the Black Rod and all the committee secretariats who made our job possible. I would especially like to thank Joanne Towner for her work on the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Also, I send thanks to the many staff members of senators, members and ministers. I found as a general rule—and it is good advice, I think—that, if you get on with the staff, you get on in this place. I have always found that a very easy role to play.

Finally and most importantly, I would like to thank and show my admiration for my wife, Alice. She has been a marvellous support to me. She has kept the home fires burning in many, many ways. She is certainly not happy that I have lost my spot, but she is happy to have me home.

Our three children, Millie, Will and Angus, have been born since I was elected. As we all know, this is an extremely difficult life for those with young children. I cannot tell you how the thought of being home will lighten the step as I leave here at midnight next Wednesday. One piece of advice obvious to all of you is that politics is only part of life. Important it may be to those of us elected, but, remember, there will not be another politician nursing you back to health when your political days are over. You ignore your partner and your family at your peril.

I also thank my mother and my late father who gave me a great start in life. Both my parents impressed on me that if you have advantages you are duty bound to try to make the world a better place. My late father had a very jaundiced view of politics, so I would expect that for me the jury would still be out as far as he was concerned. I also thank my five sisters and my brother and our extended family. I have tried to live by the rule `family first, last and always', and so do they.

So, colleagues, I come to the end of this particular political road, and I will leave you with two thoughts. Firstly, in politics, unlike in most other careers, tomorrow is always another day; and, secondly, Churchill's advice on his deathbed to all politicians: never give up, never give up, never give up. Thank you for your generous comments about me, mostly thoroughly undeserved. I always think that in life it is not how you see yourself, it is how others see you. I think I am a bit naughty to be a gentleman but, anyway, there have been some nice comments made about me. I wish God's speed to you all.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to give my final speech with a sense of both gratitude and disappointment. I am grateful for the opportunity to have served the people of Victoria and the Liberal Party in the Howard government. I am, of course, disappointed that my term has been so brief. Politics and disappointments go hand in hand. I do not hide that; I accept it as part of the game.

speech.para: Notwithstanding this, I am so grateful for the honour that was bestowed upon me by the Liberal Party preselectors in May 1997. I leave this place with a renewed sense of the immense value of our political and parliamentary institutions and a deep and abiding respect for the values and philosophies of the Liberal Party. It is a party that I am proud and honoured to be a member of. It is a party that has the inherent ability to renew itself.

I am very proud of the Howard government and all that it has achieved in such a short time. I am proud of John Howard, Tim Fischer and Peter Costello's leadership. In the two short years that I have been in this place, the government's achievements, if they were listed, would run to several pages. They include, but are certainly not limited to: bringing down interest rates to their lowest since 1970 and therefore making home ownership affordable again; bringing inflation down to just over one per cent—again, the lowest in 30 years; turning a $10 billion deficit into a budget surplus of $5.4 billion and reducing government debt by $24 billion; the second privatisation of Telstra, with its $1 billion social bonus; the Native Title Amendment Act; the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate; Work for the Dole; the common youth allowance; and, before us now, the biggest tax reform since Federation. All that and more in just two years.

Before my term began, the government secured, in its first year, the Telstra sale that gave us the $1 billion environmental heritage fund, and dramatic industrial relations reform and gun law reform. Measured on fiscal, monetary, micro-economic, macro-economic and social indicators, without doubt this is the most reforming and successful government in Australia's history. And it has done all of this without the luxury of a majority in this place. I leave the Senate with a deep confidence that the rest of the Howard government's agenda will be implemented in the coming years.

Madam President, I would like to pay tribute to the other retiring senators who have spoken before me tonight. They have reflected on longer and far more distinguished careers than mine. They will be a great loss to parliament. I have been warmed and encouraged greatly by the sense of camaraderie, openness and honesty that are being displayed tonight. In particular, I am very proud to share this valedictory—if you can be proud to share a valedictory—with people whom I admire and have come to know. Can I say how appreciative I am of those warm thoughts that have been extended to me tonight. Like my colleague Senator Macdonald, I feel somewhat unworthy and overwhelmed. But it has been a honour and a privilege to get to know some of you well, and I will leave on 30 June with my respect for the Senate and its institution high.

When I gave my first speech on 3 September 1997, I outlined the values and beliefs that have guided me thus far in life. I spoke of the issues that were of great concern to me and where I hoped to make a contribution. We have had only 30 sitting weeks since I delivered that speech, less than 21 months of government. In that short time, many of the fundamental issues I raised have begun to be addressed.

For example, in my key policy interest area of unemployment, the unemployment rate has dropped by nearly 1½ per cent since the election of the Howard government; 400,000 new jobs have been created; and, whilst unemployment is still undoubtedly too high, it is coming down.

I spoke at length that afternoon about the inherent disincentive to work within our social security system and I talked specifically of the welfare state and the subsequent entitlement mentality that has grown up around it. The youth allowance is just one measure which has started to address this issue. It has taken away the financial incentive for young people to drop out of school and to go on the dole rather than study.

On a larger scale, the ANTS package fundamentally addresses the poverty trap of which I spoke that day; the trap that faces many low and middle income working people coming off welfare. Due to the clawback of benefits, they are hit with effective marginal tax rates of around 80 per cent—far more than the richest Australians pay.

A social security system is a critical safety net in any developed, caring society. But we must do everything that we can to prevent it from becoming a place of first refuge; a comfortable hammock. We must do this, not because of financial considerations but, because having a job, the feeling of making a contribution to society, is often so important for an individual's self-esteem and confidence.

The introduction of Work for the Dole is an excellent example of the concept of reciprocal obligation that I talked of in my first speech. I have had the opportunity to visit many Work for the Dole projects around Victoria and have found the young people stimulated, enthusiastic and imbued with a renewed sense of achievement and contribution. It is a fine program, addressing a real need.

On a more sobering note, our youth suicide rate continues to escalate. Last year 510 young people, many of them very young, killed themselves. According to the ABS, 417 of these 510 were young men and boys. It is a commonly recited fact that Australia has one of the highest rates of youth suicide for young men in the world. Why is this? The answer is: there is no simple answer.

Without question, young people today are growing up in a very complex world, a world of great uncertainty. Increasing family dislocation, fear of the unknown and fear of failing in an unrelenting, demanding society are all undoubtedly factors.

I would like to see all of us, government and the community, do more to identify the risk factors and address the issues in a preventive fashion. There are many worthy programs aimed at prevention. Unfortunately, the fact that they often straddle many government departments, perhaps at different levels of government, means that they are often underfunded. As a result, more young people enter a dangerous and tumultuous time not equipped with the life skills they need to get through it.

I have just returned from Indonesia as part of the official Australian Observer Mission led by Senator Ferguson. Whilst it is inappropriate to comment on the mission itself, until Senator Ferguson has had an opportunity to present the report to parliament, I do want to say how humbled I was by the strength with which the Indonesian people have grasped democracy and the commitment they made to the whole democratic process.

Many people, but particularly young people and students, worked for weeks with little sleep. Hundreds of thousands of them worked as domestic election monitors, choosing to stay outside of the party political system—although they were obviously keenly interested in politics—because their commitment to reform and democracy, was stronger than their desire to join a political party and, possibly, further their own interests. The same applies to many academic and university staff. In fact universities closed down for three weeks over the election campaign to enable students and staff to work on the monitoring task. None of this is surprising when we consider the risks that the students had previously taken in calling for democratic reforms.

I found their belief in the value of democracy and trust in the election process very reassuring, but also confronting. I returned to Australia determined to value our democratic traditions and heritage far more. I am a great supporter of Minister David Kemp's initiatives to promote civics education in our schools through the Discovering Democracy Program. We have a great tradition which we should treasure and work harder to protect.

I came away from Indonesia with a renewed appreciation for the vitality, vision and potential of young people. Certainly the young people, and particularly the students, of Indonesia can stand tall as they contemplate a brighter, freer, democratic future. Many of them paid a great price; some of them the ultimate price.

The students of Indonesia demonstrated to me that it is not a cushy paid job in a nice student union building that builds democratic movements and creates effective advocacy. I believe tertiary students, as adults, are capable of making their own decisions about how and where they spend their money and with whom they choose to associate. Many of you know that I am extremely passionate about voluntary student unionism. I would like to thank Senators Abetz, Campbell and Ellison, and all of my colleagues, who share this passion for universal freedom of association. Many of you have worked tirelessly in this place for much longer than I have. I am disappointed to leave before the final race is run, but I leave knowing that the baton is in solid hands and I know you will not give up the fight.

When I entered the Senate I didn't fully appreciate the satisfaction and enjoyment I would get from constituent meetings with my fellow Victorians. I anticipated the large amount of time senators spend in sittings and committees, however, I did not expect to meet so many wonderful people deeply interested in their local communities. I was not prepared for the buzz and the satisfaction I received from helping those people in some small way. I was delighted to be able to make dozens of trips to regional centres in country Victoria, from as far as Mildura in the Mallee to Marlo in East Gippsland. I experienced incredible warmth and hospitality wherever I went. I will certainly cherish those memories forever.

I conclude these brief remarks here tonight and hope you will forgive me for not spending too long on reminiscing about my experiences in this place because they have been so short, but rather to, once again, spell out some of the values that I hold dear. I would like to thank all my Senate colleagues for their advice, assistance and friendship. I have learned a lot from many of you and consider myself privileged to have had the opportunity to work with you. To the leader of the government, Robert Hill—tired Robert Hill—thank you especially for your warm support and spirited leadership. To the other Senate officials who work tirelessly to make our lives here run smoothly, thank you. To all my friends in the Victorian division of the Liberal Party—too many to name but you know who you are—thank you for sticking by me in a difficult time. I cannot express in words how much your support has meant to me. To my staff, both past and present, friends, family and my dear husband Joe, your continued faith in me has brought me through a difficult time. I will never forget your patience, love and encouragement.
Madam President, to you and all my colleagues, thank you.
I hope that fate will return me here some day. So I say, au revoir.

talk.start.para: —My best wishes to those of my colleagues who will be retiring next week. The Senate stands adjourned until 9.30 this morning.
